The desired maximum width of the cell, in characters. If this property is set to -1, the width will be calculated automatically.
For cell renderers that ellipsize or wrap text; this property controls the maximum reported width of the cell. The cell should not receive any greater allocation unless it is set to expand in its `GtkCellLayout` and all of the cell's siblings have received their natural width.

property.name: GtkCellRendererText:placeholder-text
property.description: The text that will be displayed in the `GtkCellRenderer` if `GtkCellRendererText:editable` is %TRUE and the cell is empty.

property.name: GtkCellRendererText:width-chars
property.description: The desired width of the cell, in characters. If this property is set to -1, the width will be calculated automatically, otherwise the cell will request either 3 characters or the property value, whichever is greater.

property.name: GtkCellRendererText:wrap-mode
property.description: Specifies how to break the string into multiple lines, if the cell renderer does not have enough room to display the entire string. This property has no effect unless the wrap-width property is set.

property.name: GtkCellRendererText:wrap-width
property.description: Specifies the minimum width at which the text is wrapped. The wrap-mode property can be used to influence at what character positions the line breaks can be placed. Setting wrap-width to -1 turns wrapping off.

signal.name: GtkCellRendererToggle::toggled
signal.description:
The ::toggled signal is emitted when the cell is toggled.
It is the responsibility of the application to update the model with the correct value to store at @path. Often this is simply the opposite of the value currently stored at @path.

parameter.name: cell_renderer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: string representation of `GtkTreePath` describing the event location

property.name: GtkCellView:cell-area
property.description:
The `GtkCellArea` rendering cells
If no area is specified when creating the cell view with gtk_cell_view_new_with_context() a horizontally oriented `GtkCellArea`Box will be used.
since 3.0

property.name: GtkCellView:cell-area-context
property.description:
The `GtkCellAreaContext` used to compute the geometry of the cell view.
A group of cell views can be assigned the same context in order to ensure the sizes and cell alignments match across all the views with the same context.
`GtkComboBox` menus uses this to assign the same context to all cell views in the menu items for a single menu (each submenu creates its own context since the size of each submenu does not depend on parent or sibling menus).
since 3.0

property.name: GtkCellView:draw-sensitive
property.description:
Whether all cells should be draw as sensitive for this view regardless of the actual cell properties (used to make menus with submenus appear sensitive when the items in submenus might be insensitive).
since 3.0

property.name: GtkCellView:fit-model
property.description:
Whether the view should request enough space to always fit the size of every row in the model (used by the combo box to ensure the combo box size doesn't change when different items are selected).
since 3.0

property.name: GtkCellView:model
property.description:
The model for cell view
since 2.10

property.name: GtkCenterBox:baseline-position
property.description: The position of the baseline aligned widget if extra space is available.

property.name: GtkCenterBox:center-widget
property.description:
The widget that is placed at the center position.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkCenterBox:end-widget
property.description:
The widget that is placed at the end position.
In vertical orientation, the end position is at the bottom. In horizontal orientation, the end position is at the trailing edge with respect to the text direction.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkCenterBox:shrink-center-last
property.description:
Whether to shrink the center widget after other children.
By default, when there's no space to give all three children their natural widths, the start and end widgets start shrinking and the center child keeps natural width until they reach minimum width.
If false, start and end widgets keep natural width and the center widget starts shrinking instead.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkCenterBox:start-widget
property.description:
The widget that is placed at the start position.
In vertical orientation, the start position is at the top. In horizontal orientation, the start position is at the leading edge with respect to the text direction.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkCenterLayout:shrink-center-last
property.description:
Whether to shrink the center widget after other children.
By default, when there's no space to give all three children their natural widths, the start and end widgets start shrinking and the center child keeps natural width until they reach minimum width.
If set to `FALSE`, start and end widgets keep natural width and the center widget starts shrinking instead.
Since: 4.12

signal.name: GtkCheckButton::activate
signal.description:
Emitted to when the check button is activated.
The `::activate` signal on `GtkCheckButton` is an action signal and emitting it causes the button to animate press then release.
Applications should never connect to this signal, but use the [signal@Gtk.CheckButton::toggled] signal.
The default bindings for this signal are all forms of the <kbd>␣</kbd> and <kbd>Enter</kbd> keys.
Since: 4.2

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkCheckButton::toggled
signal.description: Emitted when the buttons's [property@Gtk.CheckButton:active] property changes.

property.name: GtkCheckButton:active
property.description:
If the check button is active.
Setting `active` to %TRUE will add the `:checked:` state to both the check button and the indicator CSS node.

property.name: GtkCheckButton:child
property.description:
The child widget.
Since: 4.8

property.name: GtkCheckButton:group
property.description: The check button whose group this widget belongs to.

property.name: GtkCheckButton:inconsistent
property.description:
If the check button is in an “in between” state.
The inconsistent state only affects visual appearance, not the semantics of the button.

property.name: GtkCheckButton:label
property.description: Text of the label inside the check button, if it contains a label widget.

property.name: GtkCheckButton:use-underline
property.description: If set, an underline in the text indicates that the following character is to be used as mnemonic.

enum.name: GtkCollation
enum.description:
Describes how a [class@Gtk.StringSorter] turns strings into sort keys to compare them.
Note that the result of sorting will in general depend on the current locale unless the mode is @GTK_COLLATION_NONE.
Since: 4.10

signal.name: GtkColorButton::activate
signal.description:
Emitted to when the color button is activated.
The `::activate` signal on `GtkMenuButton` is an action signal and emitting it causes the button to pop up its dialog.
Since: 4.4

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkColorButton::color-set
signal.description:
Emitted when the user selects a color.
When handling this signal, use [method@Gtk.ColorChooser.get_rgba] to find out which color was just selected.
Note that this signal is only emitted when the user changes the color. If you need to react to programmatic color changes as well, use the notify::rgba signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

property.name: GtkColorButton:modal
property.description: Whether the color chooser dialog should be modal.

property.name: GtkColorButton:show-editor
property.description:
Whether the color chooser should open in editor mode.
This property should be used in cases where the palette in the editor would be redundant, such as when the color button is already part of a palette.

property.name: GtkColorButton:title
property.description: The title of the color chooser dialog

signal.name: GtkColorChooser::color-activated
signal.description:
Emitted when a color is activated from the color chooser.
This usually happens when the user clicks a color swatch, or a color is selected and the user presses one of the keys Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.ColorDialog] and [class@Gtk.ColorDialogButton] instead of widgets implementing `GtkColorChooser`

parameter.name: chooser
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkColorChooser:rgba
property.description:
The currently selected color, as a `GdkRGBA` struct.
The property can be set to change the current selection programmatically.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.ColorDialog] and [class@Gtk.ColorDialogButton] instead of widgets implementing `GtkColorChooser`

property.name: GtkColorChooser:use-alpha
property.description:
Whether colors may have alpha (translucency).
When ::use-alpha is %FALSE, the `GdkRGBA` struct obtained via the [property@Gtk.ColorChooser:rgba] property will be forced to have alpha == 1.
Implementations are expected to show alpha by rendering the color over a non-uniform background (like a checkerboard pattern).
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.ColorDialog] and [class@Gtk.ColorDialogButton] instead of widgets implementing `GtkColorChooser`

property.name: GtkColorChooserDialog:show-editor
property.description:
Whether the color chooser dialog is showing the single-color editor.
It can be set to switch the color chooser into single-color editing mode.

property.name: GtkColorChooserWidget:show-editor
property.description:
%TRUE when the color chooser is showing the single-color editor.
It can be set to switch the color chooser into single-color editing mode.

property.name: GtkColorDialog:modal
property.description:
Whether the color chooser dialog is modal.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkColorDialog:title
property.description:
A title that may be shown on the color chooser dialog.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkColorDialog:with-alpha
property.description:
Whether colors may have alpha (translucency).
When with-alpha is false, the color that is selected will be forced to have alpha == 1.
Since: 4.10

signal.name: GtkColorDialogButton::activate
signal.description:
Emitted when the color dialog button is activated.
The `::activate` signal on `GtkColorDialogButton` is an action signal and emitting it causes the button to pop up its dialog.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkColorDialogButton:dialog
property.description:
The `GtkColorDialog` that contains parameters for the color chooser dialog.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkColorDialogButton:rgba
property.description:
The selected color.
This property can be set to give the button its initial color, and it will be updated to reflect the users choice in the color chooser dialog.
Listen to `notify::rgba` to get informed about changes to the buttons color.
Since: 4.10

signal.name: GtkColumnView::activate
signal.description:
Emitted when a row has been activated by the user, usually via activating the GtkListBase|list.activate-item action.
This allows for a convenient way to handle activation in a columnview. See [method@Gtk.ListItem.set_activatable] for details on how to use this signal.

property.name: GtkColumnView:columns
property.description: The list of columns.

property.name: GtkColumnView:enable-rubberband
property.description: Allow rubberband selection.

property.name: GtkColumnView:header-factory
property.description:
Factory for creating header widgets.
The factory must be for configuring [class@Gtk.ListHeader] objects.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnView:model
property.description: Model for the items displayed.

property.name: GtkColumnView:reorderable
property.description: Whether columns are reorderable.

property.name: GtkColumnView:row-factory
property.description:
The factory used for configuring rows.
The factory must be for configuring [class@Gtk.ColumnViewRow] objects.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnView:show-column-separators

property.name: GtkColumnView:show-row-separators
property.description: Show separators between rows.

property.name: GtkColumnView:single-click-activate
property.description: Activate rows on single click and select them on hover.

property.name: GtkColumnView:sorter
property.description: Sorter with the sorting choices of the user.

property.name: GtkColumnView:tab-behavior
property.description:
Behavior of the <kbd>Tab</kbd> key
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewCell:child
property.description:
Widget used for display.

property.name: GtkColumnViewCell:focusable
property.description:
If the item can be focused with the keyboard.

property.name: GtkColumnViewCell:item

Displayed item.

property.name: GtkColumnViewCell:position

property.name: GtkColumnViewCell:selected

If the item is currently selected.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:column-view

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:expand
property.description: Column gets share of extra width allocated to the view.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:factory
property.description:
Factory for populating list items.
The factory must be for configuring [class@Gtk.ColumnViewCell] objects.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:fixed-width
property.description: If not -1, this is the width that the column is allocated, regardless of the size of its content.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:header-menu
property.description: Menu model used to create the context menu for the column header.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:id
property.description:
An ID for the column.
GTK is not currently using the ID for anything, but it can be used by applications when saving column view configurations.
It is up to applications to ensure uniqueness of IDs.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:resizable
property.description: Whether this column is resizable.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:sorter
property.description: Sorter for sorting items according to this column.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:title
property.description: Title displayed in the header.

property.name: GtkColumnViewColumn:visible
property.description: Whether this column is visible.

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:accessible-description
property.description:
The accessible description to set on the row.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:accessible-label
property.description:
The accessible label to set on the row.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:activatable
property.description:
If the row can be activated by the user.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:focusable
property.description:
If the row can be focused with the keyboard.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:item
property.description:
The item for this row.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:position
property.description:
Position of the row.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:selectable
property.description:
If the row can be selected by the user.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewRow:selected
property.description:
If the item in the row is currently selected.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkColumnViewSorter:primary-sort-column
property.description:
The primary sort column.
The primary sort column is the one that displays the triangle in a column view header.
Since: 4.10

property.name: GtkColumnViewSorter:primary-sort-order
property.description:
The primary sort order.
The primary sort order determines whether the triangle displayed in the column view header of the primary sort column points upwards or downwards.
Since: 4.10

signal.name: GtkComboBox::activate
signal.description:
Emitted to when the combo box is activated.
The `::activate` signal on `GtkComboBox` is an action signal and emitting it causes the combo box to pop up its dropdown.
Since: 4.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkComboBox::changed
signal.description:
Emitted when the active item is changed.
The can be due to the user selecting a different item from the list, or due to a call to [method@Gtk.ComboBox.set_active_iter]. It will also be emitted while typing into the entry of a combo box with an entry.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkComboBox::format-entry-text

parameter.name: combo
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the [struct@Gtk.TreePath] string from the combo box's current model to format text for

signal.return: a newly allocated string representing @path for the current `GtkComboBox` model.

signal.name: GtkComboBox::move-active
signal.description:
Emitted to move the active selection.
This is an [keybinding signal](class.SignalAction.html).

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkComboBox::popdown
signal.description:
Emitted to popdown the combo box list.
This is an [keybinding signal](class.SignalAction.html).
The default bindings for this signal are Alt+Up and Escape.

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: whether the combo box was popped down

signal.name: GtkComboBox::popup
signal.description:
Emitted to popup the combo box list.
This is an [keybinding signal](class.SignalAction.html).
The default binding for this signal is Alt+Down.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object that received the signal

property.name: GtkComboBox:active
property.description:
The item which is currently active.
If the model is a non-flat treemodel, and the active item is not an immediate child of the root of the tree, this property has the value `gtk_tree_path_get_indices (path)[0]`, where `path` is the [struct@Gtk.TreePath] of the active item.

property.name: GtkComboBox:active-id
property.description: The value of the ID column of the active row.

property.name: GtkComboBox:button-sensitivity
property.description: Whether the dropdown button is sensitive when the model is empty.

property.name: GtkComboBox:child
property.description: The child widget.

property.name: GtkComboBox:entry-text-column
property.description:
The model column to associate with strings from the entry.
This is property only relevant if the combo was created with [property@Gtk.ComboBox:has-entry] is %TRUE.

property.name: GtkComboBox:has-entry
property.description: Whether the combo box has an entry.

property.name: GtkComboBox:has-frame
property.description: The `has-frame` property controls whether a frame is drawn around the entry.

property.name: GtkComboBox:id-column
property.description: The model column that provides string IDs for the values in the model, if != -1.

property.name: GtkComboBox:model
property.description: The model from which the combo box takes its values.

property.name: GtkComboBox:popup-fixed-width
property.description: Whether the popup's width should be a fixed width matching the allocated width of the combo box.

property.name: GtkComboBox:popup-shown
property.description:
Whether the combo boxes dropdown is popped up.
Note that this property is mainly useful, because it allows you to connect to notify::popup-shown.

property.name: GtkConstraint:constant
property.description: The constant value to be added to the [property@Gtk.Constraint:source-attribute].

property.name: GtkConstraint:multiplier
property.description: The multiplication factor to be applied to the [property@Gtk.Constraint:source-attribute].

property.name: GtkConstraint:relation
property.description: The order relation between the terms of the constraint.

property.name: GtkConstraint:source
property.description:
The source of the constraint.
The constraint will set the [property@Gtk.Constraint:target-attribute] property of the target using the [property@Gtk.Constraint:source-attribute] property of the source.

property.name: GtkConstraint:source-attribute
property.description: The attribute of the [property@Gtk.Constraint:source] read by the constraint.

property.name: GtkConstraint:strength
property.description:
The strength of the constraint.
The strength can be expressed either using one of the symbolic values of the [enum@Gtk.ConstraintStrength] enumeration, or any positive integer value.

property.name: GtkConstraint:target
property.description:
The target of the constraint.
The constraint will set the [property@Gtk.Constraint:target-attribute] property of the target using the [property@Gtk.Constraint:source-attribute] property of the source widget.

property.name: GtkConstraint:target-attribute
property.description: The attribute of the [property@Gtk.Constraint:target] set by the constraint.

enum.name: GtkConstraintAttribute
enum.description: The widget attributes that can be used when creating a [class@Constraint].

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: No attribute, used for constant relations

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: The left edge of a widget, regardless of text direction

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: The right edge of a widget, regardless of text direction

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_TOP
parameter.parameter_description: The top edge of a widget

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_BOTTOM
parameter.parameter_description: The bottom edge of a widget

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_START
parameter.parameter_description: The leading edge of a widget, depending on text direction; equivalent to %GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_LEFT for LTR languages, and %GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_RIGHT for RTL ones

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_END
parameter.parameter_description: The trailing edge of a widget, depending on text direction; equivalent to %GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_RIGHT for LTR languages, and %GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_LEFT for RTL ones

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_CENTER_X
parameter.parameter_description: The center of a widget, on the horizontal axis

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_ATTRIBUTE_CENTER_Y
parameter.parameter_description: The center of a widget, on the vertical axis

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:max-height
property.description: The maximum height of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:max-width
property.description: The maximum width of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:min-height
property.description: The minimum height of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:min-width
property.description: The minimum width of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:name
property.description: A name that identifies the `GtkConstraintGuide`, for debugging.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:nat-height
property.description: The preferred, or natural, height of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:nat-width
property.description: The preferred, or natural, width of the guide.

property.name: GtkConstraintGuide:strength
property.description: The `GtkConstraintStrength` to be used for the constraint on the natural size of the guide.

enum.name: GtkConstraintRelation
enum.description: The relation between two terms of a constraint.

enum.name: GtkConstraintStrength
enum.description:
The strength of a constraint, expressed as a symbolic constant.
The strength of a [class@Constraint] can be expressed with any positive integer; the values of this enumeration can be used for readability.

parameter.name: GTK_CONSTRAINT_STRENGTH_REQUIRED
parameter.parameter_description: The constraint is required towards solving the layout

enum.name: GtkConstraintVflParserError
enum.description: Domain for VFL parsing errors.

enum.name: GtkContentFit
enum.description:
Controls how a content should be made to fit inside an allocation.
Since: 4.8

parameter.name: GTK_CONTENT_FIT_FILL
parameter.parameter_description: Make the content fill the entire allocation, without taking its aspect ratio in consideration. The resulting content will appear as stretched if its aspect ratio is different from the allocation aspect ratio.

parameter.name: GTK_CONTENT_FIT_CONTAIN
parameter.parameter_description: Scale the content to fit the allocation, while taking its aspect ratio in consideration. The resulting content will appear as letterboxed if its aspect ratio is different from the allocation aspect ratio.

parameter.name: GTK_CONTENT_FIT_COVER
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the entire allocation, while taking the content aspect ratio in consideration. The resulting content will appear as clipped if its aspect ratio is different from the allocation aspect ratio.

parameter.name: GTK_CONTENT_FIT_SCALE_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: The content is scaled down to fit the allocation, if needed, otherwise its original size is used.

enum.name: GtkCornerType
enum.description:
Specifies which corner a child widget should be placed in when packed into a `GtkScrolledWindow.`
This is effectively the opposite of where the scroll bars are placed.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_TOP_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the right and bottom of the widget (default behaviour).

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_BOTTOM_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the top and right of the widget.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_TOP_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the left and bottom of the widget.

parameter.name: GTK_CORNER_BOTTOM_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Place the scrollbars on the top and left of the widget.

enum.name: GtkCssParserError
enum.description:
Errors that can occur while parsing CSS.
These errors are unexpected and will cause parts of the given CSS to be ignored.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_PARSER_ERROR_SYNTAX
parameter.parameter_description: The given text does not form valid syntax

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_PARSER_ERROR_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: The given name has not been defined

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_PARSER_ERROR_UNKNOWN_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: The given value is not correct

enum.name: GtkCssParserWarning
enum.description:
Warnings that can occur while parsing CSS.
Unlike `GtkCssParserError`s, warnings do not cause the parser to skip any input, but they indicate issues that should be fixed.

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_PARSER_WARNING_DEPRECATED
parameter.parameter_description: The given construct is deprecated and will be removed in a future version

parameter.name: GTK_CSS_PARSER_WARNING_SYNTAX
parameter.parameter_description: A syntax construct was used that should be avoided

signal.name: GtkCssProvider::parsing-error
signal.description:
Signals that a parsing error occurred.
The expected error values are in the [error@Gtk.CssParserError] and [enum@Gtk.CssParserWarning] enumerations.
The @path, @line and @position describe the actual location of the error as accurately as possible.
Parsing errors are never fatal, so the parsing will resume after the error. Errors may however cause parts of the given data or even all of it to not be parsed at all. So it is a useful idea to check that the parsing succeeds by connecting to this signal.
Errors in the [enum@Gtk.CssParserWarning] enumeration should not be treated as fatal errors.
Note that this signal may be emitted at any time as the css provider may opt to defer parsing parts or all of the input to a later time than when a loading function was called.

parameter.name: provider
parameter.parameter_description: the provider that had a parsing error

property.name: GtkCssProvider:prefers-color-scheme
GtkCssProvider:prefers-contrast
property.description:
Define the contrast mode to use for the user interface.
When set to [enum@Gtk.InterfaceContrast.MORE] or [enum@Gtk.InterfaceContrast.LESS], the UI is rendered in high or low contrast.
When set to [enum@Gtk.InterfaceContrast.NO_PREFERENCE] (the default), the user interface will be rendered in default mode.
This setting is be available for media queries in CSS:
```css @media (prefers-contrast: more) { // some style with high contrast } ```
Changing this setting will cause a re-render of the style sheet.
Since: 4.20

enum.name: GtkDebugFlags
enum.description:
Flags to use with gtk_set_debug_flags().
Settings these flags causes GTK to print out different types of debugging information. Some of these flags are only available when GTK has been configured with `-Ddebug=true`.

parameter.name: GTK_DEBUG_ACTIONS
parameter.parameter_description: Information about actions and menu models

parameter.name: GTK_DEBUG_SNAPSHOT
parameter.parameter_description: Include debug render nodes in the generated snapshots

parameter.name: GTK_DEBUG_CSS
parameter.parameter_description:
Information about deprecated CSS features.
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: GTK_DEBUG_BUILDER
parameter.parameter_description:
Information about deprecated GtkBuilder features.
Since: 4.18

parameter.name: GTK_DEBUG_TOUCHSCREEN
parameter.parameter_description:
Show touch UI elements for pointer events.
Since: 4.20

enum.name: GtkDeleteType
enum.description: Passed to various keybinding signals for deleting text.

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_WORD_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Delete only the portion of the word to the left/right of cursor if we’re in the middle of a word.

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_DISPLAY_LINES
parameter.parameter_description: Delete display-lines. Display-lines refers to the visible lines, with respect to the current line breaks. As opposed to paragraphs, which are defined by line breaks in the input.

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_DISPLAY_LINE_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Delete only the portion of the display-line to the left/right of cursor.

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_PARAGRAPH_ENDS
parameter.parameter_description: Delete to the end of the paragraph. Like C-k in Emacs (or its reverse).

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_PARAGRAPHS
parameter.parameter_description: Delete entire line. Like C-k in pico.

parameter.name: GTK_DELETE_WHITESPACE
parameter.parameter_description: Delete only whitespace. Like M-\ in Emacs.

signal.name: GtkDialog::close
signal.description:
Emitted when the user uses a keybinding to close the dialog.
This is a [keybinding signal](class.SignalAction.html).
The default binding for this signal is the Escape key.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.Window] instead

signal.name: GtkDialog::response
signal.description:
Emitted when an action widget is clicked.
The signal is also emitted when the dialog receives a delete event, and when [method@Gtk.Dialog.response] is called. On a delete event, the response ID is %GTK_RESPONSE_DELETE_EVENT. Otherwise, it depends on which action widget was clicked.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.Window] instead

parameter.name: dialog
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

property.name: GtkDialog:use-header-bar
property.description:
%TRUE if the dialog uses a headerbar for action buttons instead of the action-area.
For technical reasons, this property is declared as an integer property, but you should only set it to %TRUE or %FALSE.
## Creating a dialog with headerbar
Builtin `GtkDialog` subclasses such as [class@Gtk.ColorChooserDialog] set this property according to platform conventions (using the [property@Gtk.Settings:gtk-dialogs-use-header] setting).
Here is how you can achieve the same:
```c g_object_get (settings, "gtk-dialogs-use-header", &header, NULL); dialog = g_object_new (GTK_TYPE_DIALOG, header, TRUE, NULL); ```
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.Window] instead

enum.name: GtkDialogError
enum.description:
Error codes in the `GTK_DIALOG_ERROR` domain that can be returned by async dialog functions.
Since: 4.10

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_ERROR_FAILED
parameter.parameter_description: Generic error condition for when an operation fails and no more specific code is applicable

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_ERROR_CANCELLED
parameter.parameter_description: The async function call was cancelled via its `GCancellable`

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_ERROR_DISMISSED
parameter.parameter_description: The operation was cancelled by the user (via a Cancel or Close button)

enum.name: GtkDialogFlags
enum.description:
Flags used to influence dialog construction.
Deprecated: 4.20: There is no replacement.

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT
parameter.parameter_description: Destroy the dialog when its parent is destroyed

parameter.name: GTK_DIALOG_USE_HEADER_BAR
parameter.parameter_description: Create dialog with actions in header bar instead of action area

enum.name: GtkDirectionType
enum.description: Focus movement types.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:attributes
property.description: The attributes to query.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:error
property.description: Error encountered while loading files.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:file
property.description: File to query.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:io-priority
property.description: Priority used when loading.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:item-type
property.description:
The type of items. See [method@Gio.ListModel.get_item_type].
Since: 4.8

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:loading
property.description: %TRUE if files are being loaded.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:monitored
property.description: %TRUE if the directory is monitored for changed.

property.name: GtkDirectoryList:n-items
property.description:
The number of items. See [method@Gio.ListModel.get_n_items].
Since: 4.8

property.name: GtkDragIcon:child
property.description: The widget to display as drag icon.

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-begin
signal.description:
Emitted on the drag source when a drag is started.
It can be used to e.g. set a custom drag icon with [method@Gtk.DragSource.set_icon].

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-cancel
signal.description:
Emitted on the drag source when a drag has failed.
The signal handler may handle a failed drag operation based on the type of error. It should return %TRUE if the failure has been handled and the default "drag operation failed" animation should not be shown.

parameter.name: reason
parameter.parameter_description: information on why the drag failed

signal.return: %TRUE if the failed drag operation has been already handled

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-end
signal.description:
Emitted on the drag source when a drag is finished.
A typical reason to connect to this signal is to undo things done in [signal@Gtk.DragSource::prepare] or [signal@Gtk.DragSource::drag-begin] handlers.

parameter.name: delete_data
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the drag was performing %GDK_ACTION_MOVE, and the data should be deleted

signal.name: GtkDragSource::prepare
signal.description:
Emitted when a drag is about to be initiated.
It returns the `GdkContentProvider` to use for the drag that is about to start. The default handler for this signal returns the value of the [property@Gtk.DragSource:content] property, so if you set up that property ahead of time, you don't need to connect to this signal.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the drag starting point

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate of the drag starting point

signal.return: a `GdkContentProvider`

property.name: GtkDragSource:actions
property.description:
The actions that are supported by drag operations from the source.
Note that you must handle the [signal@Gtk.DragSource::drag-end] signal if the actions include %GDK_ACTION_MOVE.

property.name: GtkDragSource:content
property.description: The data that is offered by drag operations from this source.

signal.name: GtkDrawingArea::resize
signal.description:
Emitted once when the widget is realized, and then each time the widget is changed while realized.
This is useful in order to keep state up to date with the widget size, like for instance a backing surface.

property.name: GtkDrawingArea:content-height
property.description: The content height.

property.name: GtkDrawingArea:content-width
property.description: The content width.

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::enter
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has entered the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::leave
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has left the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::motion
signal.description: Emitted when the pointer moves inside the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:contains-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer of a Drag-and-Drop operation is in the controller's widget or a descendant.
See also [property@Gtk.DropControllerMotion:is-pointer].
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::enter], but after [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::leave] is emitted.

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:drop
property.description:
The ongoing drop operation over the controller's widget or its descendant.
If no drop operation is going on, this property returns %NULL.
The event controller should not modify the @drop, but it might want to query its properties.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::enter], but after [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::leave] is emitted.

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:is-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget itself, as opposed to in a descendent widget.
See also [property@Gtk.DropControllerMotion:contains-pointer].
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::enter], but after [signal@Gtk.DropControllerMotion::leave] is emitted.

signal.name: GtkDropDown::activate
signal.description:
Emitted to when the drop down is activated.
The `::activate` signal on `GtkDropDown` is an action signal and emitting it causes the drop down to pop up its dropdown.
Since: 4.6

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

property.name: GtkDropDown:enable-search
property.description:
Whether to show a search entry in the popup.
Note that search requires [property@Gtk.DropDown:expression] to be set.

property.name: GtkDropDown:expression
property.description:
An expression to evaluate to obtain strings to match against the search term.
See [property@Gtk.DropDown:enable-search] for how to enable search. If [property@Gtk.DropDown:factory] is not set, the expression is also used to bind strings to labels produced by a default factory.

property.name: GtkDropDown:factory
property.description: Factory for populating list items.

property.name: GtkDropDown:header-factory
property.description:
The factory for creating header widgets for the popup.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkDropDown:list-factory
property.description:
The factory for populating list items in the popup.
If this is not set, [property@Gtk.DropDown:factory] is used.

property.name: GtkDropDown:model
property.description: Model for the displayed items.

property.name: GtkDropDown:search-match-mode
property.description:
The match mode for the search filter.
Since: 4.12

property.name: GtkDropDown:selected
property.description:
The position of the selected item.
If no item is selected, the property has the value %GTK_INVALID_LIST_POSITION.

property.name: GtkDropDown:selected-item
property.description: The selected item.

property.name: GtkDropDown:show-arrow
property.description:
Whether to show an arrow within the GtkDropDown widget.
Since: 4.6

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::accept
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when a drop operation is about to begin.
If the drop is not accepted, %FALSE will be returned and the drop target will ignore the drop. If %TRUE is returned, the drop is accepted for now but may be rejected later via a call to [method@Gtk.DropTarget.reject] or ultimately by returning %FALSE from a [signal@Gtk.DropTarget::drop] handler.
The default handler for this signal decides whether to accept the drop based on the formats provided by the @drop.
If the decision whether the drop will be accepted or rejected depends on the data, this function should return %TRUE, the [property@Gtk.DropTarget:preload] property should be set and the value should be inspected via the ::notify:value signal, calling [method@Gtk.DropTarget.reject] if required.
signal.return: %TRUE if @drop is accepted

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::drop
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the user drops the data onto the widget.
The signal handler must determine whether the pointer position is in a drop zone or not. If it is not in a drop zone, it returns %FALSE and no further processing is necessary.
Otherwise, the handler returns %TRUE. In this case, this handler will accept the drop. The handler is responsible for using the given @value and performing the drop operation.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: whether the drop was accepted at the given pointer position

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::enter
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the pointer enters the widget.
It can be used to set up custom highlighting.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation or `GDK_ACTION_NONE` if dropping is not supported at the current @x,@y location.

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::leave
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the pointer leaves the widget.
Its main purpose it to undo things done in [signal@Gtk.DropTarget::enter].

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::motion
signal.description: Emitted while the pointer is moving over the drop target.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation or `GDK_ACTION_NONE` if dropping is not supported at the current @x,@y location.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:actions
property.description: The `GdkDragActions` that this drop target supports.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:current-drop
property.description:
The `GdkDrop` that is currently being performed.
Since: 4.4

property.name: GtkDropTarget:drop
property.description:
The `GdkDrop` that is currently being performed.
Deprecated: 4.4: Use [property@Gtk.DropTarget:current-drop] instead

property.name: GtkDropTarget:formats
property.description: The `GdkContentFormats` that determine the supported data formats.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:preload
property.description:
Whether the drop data should be preloaded when the pointer is only hovering over the widget but has not been released.
Setting this property allows finer grained reaction to an ongoing drop at the cost of loading more data.
The default value for this property is %FALSE to avoid downloading huge amounts of data by accident.
For example, if somebody drags a full document of gigabytes of text from a text editor across a widget with a preloading drop target, this data will be downloaded, even if the data is ultimately dropped elsewhere.
For a lot of data formats, the amount of data is very small (like %GDK_TYPE_RGBA), so enabling this property does not hurt at all. And for local-only Drag-and-Drop operations, no data transfer is done, so enabling it there is free.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:value
property.description:
The value for this drop operation.
This is %NULL if the data has not been loaded yet or no drop operation is going on.
Data may be available before the [signal@Gtk.DropTarget::drop] signal gets emitted - for example when the [property@Gtk.DropTarget:preload] property is set. You can use the ::notify signal to be notified of available data.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::accept
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when a drop operation is about to begin.
If the drop is not accepted, %FALSE will be returned and the drop target will ignore the drop. If %TRUE is returned, the drop is accepted for now but may be rejected later via a call to [method@Gtk.DropTargetAsync.reject_drop] or ultimately by returning %FALSE from a [signal@Gtk.DropTargetAsync::drop] handler.
The default handler for this signal decides whether to accept the drop based on the formats provided by the @drop.
If the decision whether the drop will be accepted or rejected needs further processing, such as inspecting the data, this function should return %TRUE and proceed as is @drop was accepted and if it decides to reject the drop later, it should call [method@Gtk.DropTargetAsync.reject_drop].
signal.return: %TRUE if @drop is accepted

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-enter
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the pointer enters the widget.
It can be used to set up custom highlighting.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-leave
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the pointer leaves the widget.
Its main purpose it to undo things done in `GtkDropTargetAsync`::drag-enter.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-motion
signal.description: Emitted while the pointer is moving over the drop target.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drop
signal.description:
Emitted on the drop site when the user drops the data onto the widget.
The signal handler must determine whether the pointer position is in a drop zone or not. If it is not in a drop zone, it returns %FALSE and no further processing is necessary.
Otherwise, the handler returns %TRUE. In this case, this handler will accept the drop. The handler must ensure that [method@Gdk.Drop.finish] is called to let the source know that the drop is done. The call to [method@Gdk.Drop.finish] must only be done when all data has been received.
To receive the data, use one of the read functions provided by [class@Gdk.Drop] such as [method@Gdk.Drop.read_async] or [method@Gdk.Drop.read_value_async].

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: whether the drop is accepted at the given pointer position

property.name: GtkDropTargetAsync:actions
property.description: The `GdkDragActions` that this drop target supports.

property.name: GtkDropTargetAsync:formats
property.description: The `GdkContentFormats` that determines the supported data formats.

signal.name: GtkEditable::changed
signal.description:
Emitted at the end of a single user-visible operation on the contents.
E.g., a paste operation that replaces the contents of the selection will cause only one signal emission (even though it is implemented by first deleting the selection, then inserting the new content, and may cause multiple ::notify::text signals to be emitted).

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::delete-text
signal.description:
Emitted when text is deleted from the widget by the user.
The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for deleting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the range of deleted text, or prevent it from being deleted entirely.
The @start_pos and @end_pos parameters are interpreted as for [method@Gtk.Editable.delete_text].

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::insert-text
signal.description:
Emitted when text is inserted into the widget by the user.
The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for inserting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the inserted text, or prevent it from being inserted entirely.

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the new text, in bytes, or -1 if new_text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position, in characters, at which to insert the new text. this is an in-out parameter. After the signal emission is finished, it should point after the newly inserted text.

property.name: GtkEditable:cursor-position
property.description: The current position of the insertion cursor in chars.

property.name: GtkEditable:editable
property.description: Whether the entry contents can be edited.

property.name: GtkEditable:enable-undo
property.description: If undo/redo should be enabled for the editable.

property.name: GtkEditable:max-width-chars
property.description: The desired maximum width of the entry, in characters.

property.name: GtkEditable:selection-bound
property.description: The position of the opposite end of the selection from the cursor in chars.

property.name: GtkEditable:text
property.description: The contents of the entry.

property.name: GtkEditable:width-chars
property.description: Number of characters to leave space for in the entry.

property.name: GtkEditable:xalign
property.description:
The horizontal alignment, from 0 (left) to 1 (right).
Reversed for RTL layouts.

property.name: GtkEditableLabel:editing
property.description: This property is %TRUE while the widget is in edit mode.

enum.name: GtkEditableProperties
enum.description:
The identifiers for [iface@Gtk.Editable] properties.
See [func@Gtk.Editable.install_properties] for details on how to implement the `GtkEditable` interface.

signal.name: GtkEmojiChooser::emoji-picked
signal.description: Emitted when the user selects an Emoji.

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the Unicode sequence for the picked Emoji, in UTF-8

signal.name: GtkEntry::activate
signal.description:
Emitted when the entry is activated.
The keybindings for this signal are all forms of the Enter key.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: The widget on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-press
signal.description: Emitted when an activatable icon is clicked.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-release
signal.description: Emitted on the button release from a mouse click over an activatable icon.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

property.name: GtkEntry:activates-default
property.description: Whether to activate the default widget when Enter is pressed.

property.name: GtkEntry:attributes
property.description:
A list of Pango attributes to apply to the text of the entry.
This is mainly useful to change the size or weight of the text.
The `PangoAttribute`'s @start_index and @end_index must refer to the [class@Gtk.EntryBuffer] text, i.e. without the preedit string.

property.name: GtkEntry:buffer
property.description: The buffer object which actually stores the text.

property.name: GtkEntry:completion
property.description:
The auxiliary completion object to use with the entry.
Deprecated: 4.10: GtkEntryCompletion will be removed in GTK 5.

property.name: GtkEntry:enable-emoji-completion
property.description: Whether to suggest Emoji replacements for :-delimited names like `:heart:`.

property.name: GtkEntry:extra-menu
property.description: A menu model whose contents will be appended to the context menu.

property.name: GtkEntry:has-frame
property.description: Whether the entry should draw a frame.

property.name: GtkEntry:im-module
property.description:
Which IM (input method) module should be used for this entry.
See [class@Gtk.IMContext].
Setting this to a non-%NULL value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the GtkSettings [property@Gtk.Settings:gtk-im-module] property.

property.name: GtkEntry:input-hints
property.description:
Additional hints that allow input methods to fine-tune their behavior.
Also see [property@Gtk.Entry:input-purpose]

property.name: GtkEntry:input-purpose
property.description:
The purpose of this text field.
This property can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.
Note that setting the purpose to %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PASSWORD or %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PIN is independent from setting [property@Gtk.Entry:visibility].

property.name: GtkEntry:invisible-char
property.description: The character to use when masking entry contents (“password mode”).

property.name: GtkEntry:invisible-char-set
property.description: Whether the invisible char has been set for the `GtkEntry`.

property.name: GtkEntry:max-length
property.description: Maximum number of characters for this entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:menu-entry-icon-primary-text
property.description:
Text for an item in the context menu to activate the primary icon action.
When the primary icon is activatable and this property has been set, a new entry in the context menu of this GtkEntry will appear with this text. Selecting that menu entry will result in the primary icon being activated, exactly in the same way as it would be activated from a mouse click.
This simplifies adding accessibility support to applications using activatable icons. The activatable icons aren't focusable when navigating the interface with the keyboard This is why Gtk recommends to also add those actions in the context menu. This set of methods greatly simplifies this, by adding a menu item that, when enabled, calls the same callback than clicking on the icon.
Since: 4.20

property.name: GtkEntry:menu-entry-icon-secondary-text
property.description:
Text for an item in the context menu to activate the secondary icon action.
When the primary icon is activatable and this property has been set, a new entry in the context menu of this GtkEntry will appear with this text. Selecting that menu entry will result in the primary icon being activated, exactly in the same way as it would be activated from a mouse click.
This simplifies adding accessibility support to applications using activatable icons. The activatable icons aren't focusable when navigating the interface with the keyboard This is why Gtk recommends to also add those actions in the context menu. This set of methods greatly simplifies this, by adding a menu item that, when enabled, calls the same callback than clicking on the icon.
Since: 4.20

property.name: GtkEntry:overwrite-mode
property.description: If text is overwritten when typing in the `GtkEntry`.

property.name: GtkEntry:placeholder-text
property.description: The text that will be displayed in the `GtkEntry` when it is empty and unfocused.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-activatable
property.description:
Whether the primary icon is activatable.
GTK emits the [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-press] and [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-release] signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.
Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-gicon
property.description: The `GIcon` to use for the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-name
property.description: The icon name to use for the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-paintable
property.description: A `GdkPaintable` to use as the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-sensitive
property.description:
Whether the primary icon is sensitive.
An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK does not emit the [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-press] and [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-release] signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.
An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-storage-type
property.description: The representation which is used for the primary icon of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-tooltip-markup
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon, with markup.
Also see [method@Gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_markup].

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-tooltip-text
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon.
Also see [method@Gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_text].

property.name: GtkEntry:progress-fraction
property.description: The current fraction of the task that's been completed.

property.name: GtkEntry:progress-pulse-step
property.description:
The fraction of total entry width to move the progress bouncing block for each pulse.
See [method@Gtk.Entry.progress_pulse].

property.name: GtkEntry:scroll-offset
property.description: Number of pixels of the entry scrolled off the screen to the left.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-activatable
property.description:
Whether the secondary icon is activatable.
GTK emits the [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-press] and [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-release] signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.
Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-gicon
property.description: The `GIcon` to use for the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-name
property.description: The icon name to use for the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-paintable
property.description: A `GdkPaintable` to use as the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-sensitive
property.description:
Whether the secondary icon is sensitive.
An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK does not emit the [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-press[ and [signal@Gtk.Entry::icon-release] signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.
An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-storage-type
property.description: The representation which is used for the secondary icon of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-tooltip-markup
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon, with markup.
Also see [method@Gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_markup].

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-tooltip-text
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon.
Also see [method@Gtk.Entry.set_icon_tooltip_text].

property.name: GtkEntry:show-emoji-icon
property.description: Whether the entry will show an Emoji icon in the secondary icon position to open the Emoji chooser.

property.name: GtkEntry:tabs
property.description: A list of tabstops to apply to the text of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:text-length
property.description: The length of the text in the `GtkEntry`.

property.name: GtkEntry:truncate-multiline
property.description: When %TRUE, pasted multi-line text is truncated to the first line.

property.name: GtkEntry:visibility
property.description: Whether the entry should show the “invisible char” instead of the actual text (“password mode”).

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::deleted-text
signal.description:
The text is altered in the default handler for this signal.
If you want access to the text after the text has been modified, use %G_CONNECT_AFTER.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was deleted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were deleted.

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::inserted-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted after text is inserted into the buffer.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was inserted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were inserted.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:length
property.description: The length (in characters) of the text in buffer.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:max-length
property.description: The maximum length (in characters) of the text in the buffer.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:text
property.description: The contents of the buffer.

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::cursor-on-match
signal.description:
Emitted when a match from the cursor is on a match of the list.
The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to [method@Gtk.EntryCompletion.set_model].

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a `GtkTreeIter` positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::insert-prefix
signal.description:
Emitted when the inline autocompletion is triggered.
The default behaviour is to make the entry display the whole prefix and select the newly inserted part.
Applications may connect to this signal in order to insert only a smaller part of the @prefix into the entry - e.g. the entry used in the `GtkFileChooser` inserts only the part of the prefix up to the next '/'.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: prefix
parameter.parameter_description: the common prefix of all possible completions

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::match-selected
signal.description:
Emitted when a match from the list is selected.
The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to [method@Gtk.EntryCompletion.set_model].

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a `GtkTreeIter` positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::no-matches
signal.description:
Emitted when the filter model has zero number of rows in completion_complete method.
In other words when `GtkEntryCompletion` is out of suggestions.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:cell-area
property.description:
The `GtkCellArea` used to layout cell renderers in the treeview column.
If no area is specified when creating the entry completion with [ctor@Gtk.EntryCompletion.new_with_area], a horizontally oriented [class@Gtk.CellAreaBox] will be used.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:inline-completion
property.description:
Determines whether the common prefix of the possible completions should be inserted automatically in the entry.
Note that this requires text-column to be set, even if you are using a custom match function.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:inline-selection
property.description: Determines whether the possible completions on the popup will appear in the entry as you navigate through them.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:minimum-key-length
property.description: The minimum key length as set for completion.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:model
property.description: The model used as data source.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-completion
property.description: Determines whether the possible completions should be shown in a popup window.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-set-width
property.description: Determines whether the completions popup window will be resized to the width of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-single-match
property.description:
Determines whether the completions popup window will shown for a single possible completion.
You probably want to set this to %FALSE if you are using [property@Gtk.EntryCompletion:inline-completion].

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:text-column
property.description:
The column of the model containing the strings.
Note that the strings must be UTF-8.

enum.name: GtkEntryIconPosition
enum.description: Specifies the side of the entry at which an icon is placed.

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_PRIMARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the beginning of the entry (depending on the text direction).

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_SECONDARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the end of the entry (depending on the text direction).

property.name: GtkEventController:name
property.description: The name for this controller, typically used for debugging purposes.

property.name: GtkEventController:propagation-limit
property.description: The limit for which events this controller will handle.

property.name: GtkEventController:propagation-phase
property.description: The propagation phase at which this controller will handle events.

property.name: GtkEventController:widget
property.description: The widget receiving the `GdkEvents` that the controller will handle.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerFocus::enter
signal.description:
Emitted whenever the focus enters into the widget or one of its descendents.
Note that this means you may not get an ::enter signal even though the widget becomes the focus location, in certain cases (such as when the focus moves from a descendent of the widget to the widget itself). If you are interested in these cases, you can monitor the [property@Gtk.EventControllerFocus:is-focus] property for changes.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerFocus::leave
signal.description:
Emitted whenever the focus leaves the widget hierarchy that is rooted at the widget that the controller is attached to.
Note that this means you may not get a ::leave signal even though the focus moves away from the widget, in certain cases (such as when the focus moves from the widget to a descendent). If you are interested in these cases, you can monitor the [property@Gtk.EventControllerFocus:is-focus] property for changes.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerFocus:contains-focus
property.description:
%TRUE if focus is contained in the controllers widget.
See [property@Gtk.EventControllerFocus:is-focus] for whether the focus is in the widget itself or inside a descendent.
When handling focus events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.EventControllerFocus::enter] or [signal@Gtk.EventControllerFocus::leave] are emitted.

property.name: GtkEventControllerFocus:is-focus
property.description:
%TRUE if focus is in the controllers widget itself, as opposed to in a descendent widget.
See also [property@Gtk.EventControllerFocus:contains-focus].
When handling focus events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.EventControllerFocus::enter] or [signal@Gtk.EventControllerFocus::leave] are emitted.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::im-update
signal.description:
Emitted whenever the input method context filters away a keypress and prevents the @controller receiving it.
See [method@Gtk.EventControllerKey.set_im_context] and [method@Gtk.IMContext.filter_keypress].

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::key-pressed
signal.description: Emitted whenever a key is pressed.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: keycode
parameter.parameter_description: the raw code of the pressed key.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons.

signal.return: %TRUE if the key press was handled, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::key-released
signal.description: Emitted whenever a key is released.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: keycode
parameter.parameter_description: the raw code of the released key.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::modifiers
signal.description: Emitted whenever the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons change.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the new state of modifier keys and pointer buttons.

signal.return: whether to ignore modifiers

signal.name: GtkEventControllerLegacy::event
signal.description: Emitted for each GDK event delivered to @controller.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event and the emission of this signal. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::enter
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has entered the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::leave
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has left the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::motion
signal.description: Emitted when the pointer moves inside the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerMotion:contains-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget or a descendant.
See also [property@Gtk.EventControllerMotion:is-pointer].
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.EventControllerMotion::enter], but after [signal@Gtk.EventControllerMotion::leave] is emitted.

property.name: GtkEventControllerMotion:is-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget itself, as opposed to in a descendent widget.
See also [property@Gtk.EventControllerMotion:contains-pointer].
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before [signal@Gtk.EventControllerMotion::enter], but after [signal@Gtk.EventControllerMotion::leave] is emitted.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::decelerate
signal.description:
Emitted after scroll is finished if the %GTK_EVENT_CONTROLLER_SCROLL_KINETIC flag is set.
@vel_x and @vel_y express the initial velocity that was imprinted by the scroll events. @vel_x and @vel_y are expressed in pixels/ms.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll
signal.description:
Signals that the widget should scroll by the amount specified by @dx and @dy.
For the representation unit of the deltas, see [method@Gtk.EventControllerScroll.get_unit].

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if the scroll event was handled, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll-begin
signal.description:
Signals that a new scrolling operation has begun.
It will only be emitted on devices capable of it.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll-end
signal.description:
Signals that a scrolling operation has finished.
It will only be emitted on devices capable of it.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerScroll:flags

enum.name: GtkEventControllerScrollFlags
enum.description: Describes the behavior of a `GtkEventControllerScroll`.

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_CONTROLLER_SCROLL_DISCRETE

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_CONTROLLER_SCROLL_PHYSICAL_DIRECTION
parameter.parameter_description:
A #GtkEventControllerScrollFlags value to prefer physical direction over logical direction (i.e. oblivious to natural scroll).
Since: 4.20

enum.name: GtkEventSequenceState

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_SEQUENCE_NONE

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_SEQUENCE_CLAIMED
parameter.parameter_description: The sequence is handled and grabbed.

signal.name: GtkExpander::activate

property.name: GtkExpander:child

property.name: GtkExpander:expanded

property.name: GtkExpander:label

property.name: GtkExpander:label-widget

property.name: GtkExpander:resize-toplevel

property.name: GtkExpander:use-markup

property.name: GtkExpander:use-underline

property.name: GtkFileChooser:action
property.description:
The type of operation that the file chooser is performing.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.FileDialog] instead

property.name: GtkFileChooser:create-folders
property.description:
Whether a file chooser not in %GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN mode will offer the user to create new folders.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.FileDialog] instead

property.name: GtkFileChooser:filter
property.description:
The current filter for selecting files that are displayed.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.FileDialog] instead

property.name: GtkFileChooser:filters
property.description:
A `GListModel` containing the filters that have been added with gtk_file_chooser_add_filter().
The returned object should not be modified. It may or may not be updated for later changes.

property.name: GtkFileChooser:select-multiple

Whether to allow multiple files to be selected.

property.name: GtkFileChooser:shortcut-folders
