function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_show_title_buttons
function.description: Returns whether this header bar shows the standard window title buttons.
function.return: true if title buttons are shown

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_title_widget
function.description:
Retrieves the title widget of the header bar.
See [method@Gtk.HeaderBar.set_title_widget].

function.name: gtk_header_bar_get_use_native_controls
function.description:
Returns whether this header bar shows platform native window controls.
Since: 4.18
function.return: true if native window controls are shown

function.name: gtk_header_bar_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkHeaderBar` widget.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_pack_end
function.description: Adds a child to the header bar, packed with reference to the end.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: the widget to be added to @bar

function.name: gtk_header_bar_pack_start
function.description: Adds a child to the header bar, packed with reference to the start.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: the widget to be added to @bar

function.name: gtk_header_bar_remove
function.description:
Removes a child from the header bar.
The child must have been added with [method@Gtk.HeaderBar.pack_start], [method@Gtk.HeaderBar.pack_end] or [method@Gtk.HeaderBar.set_title_widget].

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_decoration_layout
function.description:
Sets the decoration layout for this header bar.
This property overrides the [property@Gtk.Settings:gtk-decoration-layout] setting.
There can be valid reasons for overriding the setting, such as a header bar design that does not allow for buttons to take room on the right, or only offers room for a single close button. Split header bars are another example for overriding the setting.
The format of the string is button names, separated by commas. A colon separates the buttons that should appear on the left from those on the right. Recognized button names are minimize, maximize, close and icon (the window icon).
For example, “icon:minimize,maximize,close” specifies an icon on the left, and minimize, maximize and close buttons on the right.

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_show_title_buttons
function.description: Sets whether this header bar shows the standard window title buttons.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: true to show standard title buttons

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_title_widget
function.description:
Sets the title for the header bar.
When set to `NULL`, the headerbar will display the title of the window it is contained in.
The title should help a user identify the current view. To achieve the same style as the builtin title, use the “title” style class.
You should set the title widget to `NULL`, for the window title label to be visible again.

parameter.name: title_widget
parameter.parameter_description: a widget to use for a title

function.name: gtk_header_bar_set_use_native_controls
function.description:
Sets whether this header bar shows native window controls.
This option shows the "stoplight" buttons on macOS. For Linux, this option has no effect.
See also [Using GTK on Apple macOS](osx.html?native-window-controls).
Since: 4.18

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: true to show native window controls

function.name: gtk_hsv_to_rgb

parameter.name: r
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the red component

parameter.name: g
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the green component

parameter.name: b
parameter.parameter_description: Return value for the blue component

function.name: gtk_icon_cache_validate
function.description: Validates the icon cache passed in the @cache and @cache_size fields of the @info structure. The validator checks that offsets specified in the cache do not point outside the mapped area, that strings look reasonable, and that pixbufs can be deserialized. The amount of validation can be controlled with the @flags field.

function.name: gtk_icon_paintable_get_file
function.description: Gets the `GFile` that was used to load the icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_paintable_get_icon_name
function.description:
Get the icon name being used for this icon.
When an icon looked up in the icon theme was not available, the icon theme may use fallback icons - either those specified to gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon() or the always-available "image-missing". The icon chosen is returned by this function.
If the icon was created without an icon theme, this function returns %NULL.
Deprecated: 4.20
function.return: the themed icon-name for the icon, or %NULL if its not a themed icon.

function.name: gtk_icon_paintable_is_symbolic
function.description:
Checks if the icon is symbolic or not.
This currently uses only the file name and not the file contents for determining this. This behaviour may change in the future.
Deprecated: 4.20
function.return: true if the icon is symbolic, false otherwise

function.name: gtk_icon_paintable_new_for_file
function.description:
Creates a `GtkIconPaintable` for a file with a given size and scale.
The icon can then be rendered by using it as a `GdkPaintable`.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: desired icon size, in application pixels

function.return: a `GtkIconPaintable` containing for the icon. Unref with g_object_unref()

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_add_resource_path
function.description:
Adds a resource path that will be looked at when looking for icons, similar to search paths.
See [method@Gtk.IconTheme.set_resource_path].
This function should be used to make application-specific icons available as part of the icon theme.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_add_search_path
function.description:
Appends a directory to the search path.
See [method@Gtk.IconTheme.set_search_path].

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: directory name to append to the icon path

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_error_quark
function.description: Registers an error quark for [class@Gtk.IconTheme] errors.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_display
function.description: Returns the display that the `GtkIconTheme` object was created for.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_for_display
function.description:
Gets the icon theme object associated with @display.
If this function has not previously been called for the given display, a new icon theme object will be created and associated with the display. Icon theme objects are fairly expensive to create, so using this function is usually a better choice than calling [ctor@Gtk.IconTheme.new] and setting the display yourself; by using this function a single icon theme object will be shared between users.
function.return: A unique `GtkIconTheme` associated with the given display. This icon theme is associated with the display and can be used as long as the display is open. Do not ref or unref it.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_icon_names
function.description: Lists the names of icons in the current icon theme.
function.return: a string array holding the names of all the icons in the theme. You must free the array using g_strfreev().

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_icon_sizes
function.description:
Returns an array of integers describing the sizes at which the icon is available without scaling.
A size of -1 means that the icon is available in a scalable format. The array is zero-terminated.
function.return: A newly allocated array describing the sizes at which the icon is available. The array should be freed with g_free() when it is no longer needed.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_resource_path
function.description:
Gets the current resource path.
See [method@Gtk.IconTheme.set_resource_path].

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_search_path
function.description:
Gets the current search path.
See [method@Gtk.IconTheme.set_search_path].
function.return: a list of icon theme path directories

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_get_theme_name
function.description: Gets the current icon theme name.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_has_gicon
function.description:
Checks whether an icon theme includes an icon for a particular `GIcon`.
Since: 4.2

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_has_icon
function.description: Checks whether an icon theme includes an icon for a particular name.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_by_gicon
function.description:
Looks up a icon for a desired size and window scale.
The icon can then be rendered by using it as a `GdkPaintable`, or you can get information such as the filename and size.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: desired icon size, in application pixels

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: text direction the icon will be displayed in

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.return: a `GtkIconPaintable` containing information about the icon. Unref with g_object_unref()

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon
function.description:
Looks up a named icon for a desired size and window scale, returning a `GtkIconPaintable`.
The icon can then be rendered by using it as a `GdkPaintable`, or you can get information such as the filename and size.
If the available @icon_name is not available and @fallbacks are provided, they will be tried in order.
If no matching icon is found, then a paintable that renders the "missing icon" icon is returned. If you need to do something else for missing icons you need to use [method@Gtk.IconTheme.has_icon].
Note that you probably want to listen for icon theme changes and update the icon. This is usually done by overriding the GtkWidgetClass.css-changed() function.

parameter.name: icon_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the icon to lookup

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: desired icon size, in application pixels

parameter.name: scale
parameter.parameter_description: the window scale this will be displayed on

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: text direction the icon will be displayed in

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags modifying the behavior of the icon lookup

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_new
function.description:
Creates a new icon theme object.
Icon theme objects are used to lookup up an icon by name in a particular icon theme. Usually, you’ll want to use [func@Gtk.IconTheme.get_for_display] rather than creating a new icon theme object for scratch.

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_resource_path
function.description:
Sets the resource paths that will be looked at when looking for icons, similar to search paths.
The resources are considered as part of the hicolor icon theme and must be located in subdirectories that are defined in the hicolor icon theme, such as `@path/16x16/actions/run.png` or `@path/scalable/actions/run.svg`.
Icons that are directly placed in the resource path instead of a subdirectory are also considered as ultimate fallback, but they are treated like unthemed icons.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: NULL-terminated array of resource paths that are searched for icons

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_search_path
function.description:
Sets the search path for the icon theme object.
When looking for an icon theme, GTK will search for a subdirectory of one or more of the directories in @path with the same name as the icon theme containing an index.theme file. (Themes from multiple of the path elements are combined to allow themes to be extended by adding icons in the user’s home directory.)
In addition if an icon found isn’t found either in the current icon theme or the default icon theme, and an image file with the right name is found directly in one of the elements of @path, then that image will be used for the icon name. (This is legacy feature, and new icons should be put into the fallback icon theme, which is called hicolor, rather than directly on the icon path.)

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: NULL-terminated array of directories that are searched for icon themes

function.name: gtk_icon_theme_set_theme_name
function.description:
Sets the name of the icon theme that the `GtkIconTheme` object uses overriding system configuration.
This function cannot be called on the icon theme objects returned from [func@Gtk.IconTheme.get_for_display].

parameter.name: theme_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of icon theme to use instead of configured theme, or %NULL to unset a previously set custom theme

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_item_at_pos
function.description:
Gets the path and cell for the icon at the given position.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_tooltip_context
function.description:
This function is supposed to be used in a `GtkWidget::query-tooltip` signal handler for `GtkIconView`. The @x, @y and @keyboard_tip values which are received in the signal handler, should be passed to this function without modification.
The return value indicates whether there is an icon view item at the given coordinates (%TRUE) or not (%FALSE) for mouse tooltips. For keyboard tooltips the item returned will be the cursor item. When %TRUE, then any of @model, @path and @iter which have been provided will be set to point to that row and the corresponding model.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate (relative to widget coordinates)

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate (relative to widget coordinates)

parameter.name: keyboard_tip
parameter.parameter_description: whether this is a keyboard tooltip or not

function.return: whether or not the given tooltip context points to an item

function.name: gtk_icon_view_get_visible_range
function.description:
Sets @start_path and @end_path to be the first and last visible path. Note that there may be invisible paths in between.
Both paths should be freed with gtk_tree_path_free() after use.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: start_path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for start of region

parameter.name: end_path
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for end of region

function.return: %TRUE, if valid paths were placed in @start_path and @end_path

function.name: gtk_icon_view_path_is_selected

Returns %TRUE if the icon pointed to by @path is currently selected. If @path does not point to a valid location, %FALSE is returned.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_scroll_to_path
function.description:
Moves the alignments of @icon_view to the position specified by @path. @row_align determines where the row is placed, and @col_align determines where @column is placed. Both are expected to be between 0.0 and 1.0. 0.0 means left/top alignment, 1.0 means right/bottom alignment, 0.5 means center.
If @use_align is %FALSE, then the alignment arguments are ignored, and the tree does the minimum amount of work to scroll the item onto the screen. This means that the item will be scrolled to the edge closest to its current position. If the item is currently visible on the screen, nothing is done.
This function only works if the model is set, and @path is a valid row on the model. If the model changes before the @icon_view is realized, the centered path will be modified to reflect this change.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: The path of the item to move to.

parameter.name: use_align
parameter.parameter_description: whether to use alignment arguments, or %FALSE.

parameter.name: row_align
parameter.parameter_description: The vertical alignment of the item specified by @path.

parameter.name: col_align
parameter.parameter_description: The horizontal alignment of the item specified by @path.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_select_all
function.description:
Selects all the icons. @icon_view must has its selection mode set to %GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_select_path
function.description:
Selects the row at @path.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

Calls a function for each selected icon. Note that the model or selection cannot be modified from within this function.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_column_spacing

Sets the ::column-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the columns of the icon view.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_columns

Sets the ::columns property which determines in how many columns the icons are arranged. If @columns is -1, the number of columns will be chosen automatically to fill the available area.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_cursor
function.description:
Sets the current keyboard focus to be at @path, and selects it. This is useful when you want to focus the user’s attention on a particular item. If @cell is not %NULL, then focus is given to the cell specified by it. Additionally, if @start_editing is %TRUE, then editing should be started in the specified cell.
This function is often followed by `gtk_widget_grab_focus (icon_view)` in order to give keyboard focus to the widget. Please note that editing can only happen when the widget is realized.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: cell
parameter.parameter_description: One of the cell renderers of @icon_view

parameter.name: start_editing
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the specified cell should start being edited.

Sets the ::item-orientation property which determines whether the labels are drawn beside the icons instead of below.

Sets the column with markup information for @icon_view to be @column. The markup column must be of type `G_TYPE_STRING`. If the markup column is set to something, it overrides the text column set by gtk_icon_view_set_text_column().

function.description:
Sets the model for a `GtkIconView`. If the @icon_view already has a model set, it will remove it before setting the new model. If @model is %NULL, then it will unset the old model.

Sets the column with pixbufs for @icon_view to be @column. The pixbuf column must be of type `GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF`

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: A column in the currently used model, or -1 to disable

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_reorderable
function.description:
This function is a convenience function to allow you to reorder models that support the `GtkTreeDragSourceIface` and the `GtkTreeDragDestIface`. Both `GtkTreeStore` and `GtkListStore` support these. If @reorderable is %TRUE, then the user can reorder the model by dragging and dropping rows. The developer can listen to these changes by connecting to the model's row_inserted and row_deleted signals. The reordering is implemented by setting up the icon view as a drag source and destination. Therefore, drag and drop can not be used in a reorderable view for any other purpose.
This function does not give you any degree of control over the order -- any reordering is allowed. If more control is needed, you should probably handle drag and drop manually.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: reorderable
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE, if the list of items can be reordered.

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_row_spacing
function.description:
Sets the ::row-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the rows of the icon view.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_selection_mode
function.description:
Sets the selection mode of the @icon_view.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_spacing
function.description:
Sets the ::spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the cells (i.e. the icon and the text) of an item.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_text_column
function.description:
Sets the column with text for @icon_view to be @column. The text column must be of type `G_TYPE_STRING`.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: column

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_cell
function.description:
Sets the tip area of @tooltip to the area which @cell occupies in the item pointed to by @path. See also gtk_tooltip_set_tip_area().
See also gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column() for a simpler alternative.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column
function.description:
If you only plan to have simple (text-only) tooltips on full items, you can use this function to have `GtkIconView` handle these automatically for you. @column should be set to the column in @icon_view’s model containing the tooltip texts, or -1 to disable this feature.
When enabled, `GtkWidget:has-tooltip` will be set to %TRUE and @icon_view will connect a `GtkWidget::query-tooltip` signal handler.
Note that the signal handler sets the text with gtk_tooltip_set_markup(), so &, <, etc have to be escaped in the text.
Deprecated: 4.10: Use [class@Gtk.GridView] instead

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: an integer, which is a valid column number for @icon_view’s model

function.name: gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_item
function.description:
Sets the tip area of @tooltip to be the area covered by the item at @path. See also gtk_icon_view_set_tooltip_column() for a simpler alternative. See also gtk_tooltip_set_tip_area().

function.name: gtk_im_context_activate_osk
function.description:
Requests the platform to show an on-screen keyboard for user input.
This method will return %TRUE if this request was actually performed to the platform, other environmental factors may result in an on-screen keyboard effectively not showing up.
Since: 4.14
function.return: %TRUE if an on-screen keyboard could be requested to the platform.

function.name: gtk_im_context_delete_surrounding
function.description:
Asks the widget that the input context is attached to delete characters around the cursor position by emitting the `::delete_surrounding` signal.
Note that @offset and @n_chars are in characters not in bytes which differs from the usage other places in `GtkIMContext`.
In order to use this function, you should first call [method@Gtk.IMContext.get_surrounding] to get the current context, and call this function immediately afterwards to make sure that you know what you are deleting. You should also account for the fact that even if the signal was handled, the input context might not have deleted all the characters that were requested to be deleted.
This function is used by an input method that wants to make substitutions in the existing text in response to new input. It is not useful for applications.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: offset from cursor position in chars; a negative value means start before the cursor.

function.name: gtk_im_context_filter_key
function.description: Allow an input method to forward key press and release events to another input method without necessarily having a `GdkEvent` available.

parameter.name: press
parameter.parameter_description: whether to forward a key press or release event

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: the surface the event is for

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device that the event is for

parameter.name: group
parameter.parameter_description: the active keyboard group for the event

function.return: %TRUE if the input method handled the key event.

function.name: gtk_im_context_filter_keypress
function.description:
Allow an input method to internally handle key press and release events.
If this function returns %TRUE, then no further processing should be done for this key event.
function.return: %TRUE if the input method handled the key event.

function.name: gtk_im_context_focus_in
function.description:
Notify the input method that the widget to which this input context corresponds has gained focus.
The input method may, for example, change the displayed feedback to reflect this change.

function.name: gtk_im_context_focus_out
function.description:
Notify the input method that the widget to which this input context corresponds has lost focus.
The input method may, for example, change the displayed feedback or reset the contexts state to reflect this change.

function.name: gtk_im_context_get_preedit_string
function.description:
Retrieve the current preedit string for the input context, and a list of attributes to apply to the string.
This string should be displayed inserted at the insertion point.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the retrieved string. The string retrieved must be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: attrs
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the retrieved attribute list. When you are done with this list, you must unreference it with [method@Pango.AttrList.unref].

parameter.name: cursor_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of cursor (in characters) within the preedit string.

function.name: gtk_im_context_get_surrounding
function.description:
Retrieves context around the insertion point.
Input methods typically want context in order to constrain input text based on existing text; this is important for languages such as Thai where only some sequences of characters are allowed.
This function is implemented by emitting the [signal@Gtk.IMContext::retrieve-surrounding] signal on the input method; in response to this signal, a widget should provide as much context as is available, up to an entire paragraph, by calling [method@Gtk.IMContext.set_surrounding].
Note that there is no obligation for a widget to respond to the `::retrieve-surrounding` signal, so input methods must be prepared to function without context.
Deprecated: 4.2: Use [method@Gtk.IMContext.get_surrounding_with_selection] instead.

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a UTF-8 encoded string of text holding context around the insertion point. If the function returns %TRUE, then you must free the result stored in this location with g_free().

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: location to store byte index of the insertion cursor within @text.

function.return: `TRUE` if surrounding text was provided; in this case you must free the result stored in `text`.

function.name: gtk_im_context_get_surrounding_with_selection
function.description:
Retrieves context around the insertion point.
Input methods typically want context in order to constrain input text based on existing text; this is important for languages such as Thai where only some sequences of characters are allowed.
This function is implemented by emitting the [signal@Gtk.IMContext::retrieve-surrounding] signal on the input method; in response to this signal, a widget should provide as much context as is available, up to an entire paragraph, by calling [method@Gtk.IMContext.set_surrounding_with_selection].
Note that there is no obligation for a widget to respond to the `::retrieve-surrounding` signal, so input methods must be prepared to function without context.
Since: 4.2

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: location to store a UTF-8 encoded string of text holding context around the insertion point. If the function returns %TRUE, then you must free the result stored in this location with g_free().

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: location to store byte index of the insertion cursor within @text.

parameter.name: anchor_index
parameter.parameter_description: location to store byte index of the selection bound within @text

function.return: `TRUE` if surrounding text was provided; in this case you must free the result stored in `text`.

function.name: gtk_im_context_reset
function.description:
Notify the input method that a change such as a change in cursor position has been made.
This will typically cause the input method to clear the preedit state.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_client_widget
function.description:
Set the client widget for the input context.
This is the `GtkWidget` holding the input focus. This widget is used in order to correctly position status windows, and may also be used for purposes internal to the input method.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the client widget. This may be %NULL to indicate that the previous client widget no longer exists.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_cursor_location
function.description:
Notify the input method that a change in cursor position has been made.
The location is relative to the client widget.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_surrounding
function.description:
Sets surrounding context around the insertion point and preedit string.
This function is expected to be called in response to the [signal@Gtk.IMContext::retrieve-surrounding] signal, and will likely have no effect if called at other times.
Deprecated: 4.2: Use [method@Gtk.IMContext.set_surrounding_with_selection] instead

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: text surrounding the insertion point, as UTF-8. the preedit string should not be included within @text

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @text, or -1 if @text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: the byte index of the insertion cursor within @text.

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_surrounding_with_selection
function.description:
Sets surrounding context around the insertion point and preedit string. This function is expected to be called in response to the [signal@Gtk.IMContext::retrieve_surrounding] signal, and will likely have no effect if called at other times.
Since: 4.2

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: text surrounding the insertion point, as UTF-8. the preedit string should not be included within @text

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @text, or -1 if @text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: cursor_index
parameter.parameter_description: the byte index of the insertion cursor within @text

parameter.name: anchor_index
parameter.parameter_description: the byte index of the selection bound within @text

function.name: gtk_im_context_set_use_preedit
function.description:
Sets whether the IM context should use the preedit string to display feedback.
If @use_preedit is %FALSE (default is %TRUE), then the IM context may use some other method to display feedback, such as displaying it in a child of the root window.

parameter.name: use_preedit
parameter.parameter_description: whether the IM context should use the preedit string.

function.name: gtk_im_context_simple_add_compose_file
function.description: Adds an additional table from the X11 compose file.

function.name: gtk_im_context_simple_add_table
function.description:
Adds an additional table to search to the input context. Each row of the table consists of @max_seq_len key symbols followed by two #guint16 interpreted as the high and low words of a #gunicode value. Tables are searched starting from the last added.
The table must be sorted in dictionary order on the numeric value of the key symbol fields. (Values beyond the length of the sequence should be zero.)
Deprecated: 4.4: Use gtk_im_context_simple_add_compose_file()

parameter.name: max_seq_len
parameter.parameter_description: Maximum length of a sequence in the table

parameter.name: n_seqs
parameter.parameter_description: number of sequences in the table

function.name: gtk_im_context_simple_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkIMContextSimple`.

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_get_context_id
function.description: Gets the id of the currently active delegate of the @context.
function.return: the id of the currently active delegate

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkIMMulticontext`.

function.name: gtk_im_multicontext_set_context_id
function.description:
Sets the context id for @context.
This causes the currently active delegate of @context to be replaced by the delegate corresponding to the new context id.
Setting this to a non-%NULL value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the [property@Gtk.Settings:gtk-im-module] property.

function.name: gtk_image_clear
function.description: Resets the image to be empty.

function.name: gtk_image_get_gicon
function.description:
Gets the `GIcon` being displayed by the `GtkImage`.
The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_GICON (see [method@Gtk.Image.get_storage_type]). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned `GIcon`.

function.name: gtk_image_get_icon_name
function.description:
Gets the icon name and size being displayed by the `GtkImage`.
The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_ICON_NAME (see [method@Gtk.Image.get_storage_type]). The returned string is owned by the `GtkImage` and should not be freed.

function.name: gtk_image_get_icon_size
function.description: Gets the icon size used by the @image when rendering icons.
function.return: the image size used by icons

function.name: gtk_image_get_paintable
function.description:
Gets the image `GdkPaintable` being displayed by the `GtkImage`.
The storage type of the image must be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY or %GTK_IMAGE_PAINTABLE (see [method@Gtk.Image.get_storage_type]). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned paintable.

function.name: gtk_image_get_pixel_size
function.description: Gets the pixel size used for named icons.
function.return: the pixel size used for named icons.

function.name: gtk_image_get_storage_type
function.description:
Gets the type of representation being used by the `GtkImage` to store image data.
If the `GtkImage` has no image data, the return value will be %GTK_IMAGE_EMPTY.

function.name: gtk_image_new
function.description: Creates a new empty `GtkImage` widget.

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_file
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkImage` displaying the file @filename.
If the file isn’t found or can’t be loaded, the resulting `GtkImage` will display a “broken image” icon. This function never returns %NULL, it always returns a valid `GtkImage` widget.
If you need to detect failures to load the file, use an image loading framework such as libglycin to load the file yourself, then create the `GtkImage` from the texture.
The storage type (see [method@Gtk.Image.get_storage_type]) of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_gicon
function.description:
Creates a `GtkImage` displaying an icon from the current icon theme.
If the icon name isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
function.return: a new `GtkImage` displaying the themed icon

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_icon_name
function.description:
Creates a `GtkImage` displaying an icon from the current icon theme.
If the icon name isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
function.return: a new `GtkImage` displaying the themed icon

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_paintable
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkImage` displaying @paintable.
The `GtkImage` does not assume a reference to the paintable; you still need to unref it if you own references. `GtkImage` will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
The `GtkImage` will track changes to the @paintable and update its size and contents in response to it.
Note that paintables are still subject to the icon size that is set on the image. If you want to display a paintable at its intrinsic size, use [class@Gtk.Picture] instead.
If @paintable is a [iface@Gtk.SymbolicPaintable], then it will be recolored with the symbolic palette from the theme.

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkImage` displaying @pixbuf.
The `GtkImage` does not assume a reference to the pixbuf; you still need to unref it if you own references. `GtkImage` will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
This is a helper for [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_paintable], and you can't get back the exact pixbuf once this is called, only a texture.
Note that this function just creates an `GtkImage` from the pixbuf. The `GtkImage` created will not react to state changes. Should you want that, you should use [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_icon_name].
Deprecated: 4.12: Use [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_paintable] and [ctor@Gdk.Texture.new_for_pixbuf] instead

function.name: gtk_image_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkImage` displaying the resource file @resource_path.
If the file isn’t found or can’t be loaded, the resulting `GtkImage` will display a “broken image” icon. This function never returns %NULL, it always returns a valid `GtkImage` widget.
If you need to detect failures to load the file, use an image loading framework such as libglycin to load the file yourself, then create the `GtkImage` from the texture.
The storage type (see [method@Gtk.Image.get_storage_type]) of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_file
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a file.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_file] for details.
::: warning Note that this function should not be used with untrusted data. Use a proper image loading framework such as libglycin, which can load many image formats into a `GdkTexture`, and then use [method@Gtk.Image.set_from_paintable].

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_gicon
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a `GIcon`.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_gicon] for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_icon_name
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a named icon.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_icon_name] for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_paintable
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a `GdkPaintable`.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_paintable] for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a `GdkPixbuf`.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_pixbuf] for details.
Note: This is a helper for [method@Gtk.Image.set_from_paintable], and you can't get back the exact pixbuf once this is called, only a paintable.
Deprecated: 4.12: Use [method@Gtk.Image.set_from_paintable] instead

function.name: gtk_image_set_from_resource
function.description:
Sets a `GtkImage` to show a resource.
See [ctor@Gtk.Image.new_from_resource] for details.

function.name: gtk_image_set_icon_size
function.description: Suggests an icon size to the theme for named icons.

function.name: gtk_image_set_pixel_size
function.description:
Sets the pixel size to use for named icons.
If the pixel size is set to a value != -1, it is used instead of the icon size set by [method@Gtk.Image.set_icon_size].

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_action_widget
function.description:
Add an activatable widget to the action area of a `GtkInfoBar`.
This also connects a signal handler that will emit the [signal@Gtk.InfoBar::response] signal on the message area when the widget is activated. The widget is appended to the end of the message areas action area.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_button
function.description:
Adds a button with the given text.
Clicking the button will emit the [signal@Gtk.InfoBar::response] signal with the given response_id. The button is appended to the end of the info bar's action area. The button widget is returned, but usually you don't need it.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_buttons
function.description:
Adds multiple buttons.
This is the same as calling [method@Gtk.InfoBar.add_button] repeatedly. The variable argument list should be %NULL-terminated as with [ctor@Gtk.InfoBar.new_with_buttons]. Each button must have both text and response ID.
Deprecated: 4.10

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then more text-response_id pairs, ending with %NULL

function.name: gtk_info_bar_add_child
function.description:
Adds a widget to the content area of the info bar.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_message_type
function.description:
Returns the message type of the message area.
Deprecated: 4.10
function.return: the message type of the message area.

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_revealed
function.description:
Returns whether the info bar is currently revealed.
Deprecated: 4.10
function.return: the current value of the [property@Gtk.InfoBar:revealed] property

function.name: gtk_info_bar_get_show_close_button
function.description:
Returns whether the widget will display a standard close button.
Deprecated: 4.10
function.return: %TRUE if the widget displays standard close button

function.name: gtk_info_bar_new
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkInfoBar` object.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_new_with_buttons
function.description:
Creates a new `GtkInfoBar` with buttons.
Button text/response ID pairs should be listed, with a %NULL pointer ending the list. A response ID can be any positive number, or one of the values in the `GtkResponseType` enumeration. If the user clicks one of these dialog buttons, GtkInfoBar will emit the [signal@Gtk.InfoBar::response] signal with the corresponding response ID.
Deprecated: 4.10

parameter.name: first_button_text
parameter.parameter_description: ext to go in first button

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: response ID for first button, then additional buttons, ending with %NULL

function.name: gtk_info_bar_remove_action_widget
function.description:
Removes a widget from the action area of @info_bar.
The widget must have been put there by a call to [method@Gtk.InfoBar.add_action_widget] or [method@Gtk.InfoBar.add_button].
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_remove_child
function.description:
Removes a widget from the content area of the info bar.
Deprecated: 4.10

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: a child that has been added to the content area

function.name: gtk_info_bar_response
function.description:
Emits the “response” signal with the given @response_id.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_default_response
function.description:
Sets the last widget in the info bar’s action area with the given response_id as the default widget for the dialog.
Pressing “Enter” normally activates the default widget.
Note that this function currently requires @info_bar to be added to a widget hierarchy.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_message_type
function.description:
Sets the message type of the message area.
GTK uses this type to determine how the message is displayed.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_response_sensitive
function.description:
Sets the sensitivity of action widgets for @response_id.
Calls `gtk_widget_set_sensitive (widget, setting)` for each widget in the info bars’s action area with the given @response_id. A convenient way to sensitize/desensitize buttons.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_revealed
function.description:
Sets whether the `GtkInfoBar` is revealed.
Changing this will make @info_bar reveal or conceal itself via a sliding transition.
Note: this does not show or hide @info_bar in the [property@Gtk.Widget:visible] sense, so revealing has no effect if [property@Gtk.Widget:visible] is %FALSE.
Deprecated: 4.10

parameter.name: revealed
parameter.parameter_description: The new value of the property

function.name: gtk_info_bar_set_show_close_button
function.description:
If true, a standard close button is shown.
When clicked it emits the response %GTK_RESPONSE_CLOSE.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gtk_init
function.description:
Initializes GTK.
This function must be called before using any other GTK functions in your GUI applications.
It will initialize everything needed to operate the toolkit. In particular, it will open the default display (see [func@Gdk.Display.get_default]).
If you are using [class@Gtk.Application], you usually don't have to call this function; the [vfunc@Gio.Application.startup] handler does it for you. Though, if you are using `GApplication` methods that will be invoked before `startup`, such as `local_command_line`, you may need to initialize GTK explicitly.
This function will terminate your program if it was unable to initialize the windowing system for some reason. If you want your program to fall back to a textual interface, call [func@Gtk.init_check] instead.
GTK calls `signal (SIGPIPE, SIG_IGN)` during initialization, to ignore SIGPIPE signals, since these are almost never wanted in graphical applications. If you do need to handle SIGPIPE for some reason, reset the handler after gtk_init(), but notice that other libraries (e.g. libdbus or gvfs) might do similar things.

function.name: gtk_init_check
function.description:
Initializes GTK.
This function does the same work as [func@Gtk.init] with only a single change: It does not terminate the program if the windowing system can’t be initialized. Instead it returns false on failure.
This way the application can fall back to some other means of communication with the user - for example a curses or command line interface.
function.return: true if the windowing system has been successfully initialized, false otherwise

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_attributes
function.description:
Gets the inscription's attribute list.

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_min_chars

Gets the `min-lines` of the inscription.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:min-lines] property.

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_nat_chars
function.description:
Gets the `nat-chars` of the inscription.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:nat-chars] property.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_nat_lines
function.description:
Gets the `nat-lines` of the inscription.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:nat-lines] property.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_text
function.description:
Gets the text that is displayed.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_text_overflow
function.description:
Gets the inscription's overflow method.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_wrap_mode
function.description:
Returns line wrap mode used by the inscription.
See [method@Gtk.Inscription.set_wrap_mode].
Since:4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_xalign

Gets the `xalign` of the inscription.

function.name: gtk_inscription_get_yalign

function.name: gtk_inscription_new

Creates a new `GtkInscription` with the given text.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_attributes

Apply attributes to the inscription text.
These attributes will not be evaluated for sizing the inscription.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_markup
function.description:
Utility function to set the text and attributes to be displayed.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:markup] property.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_min_chars
function.description:
Sets the `min-chars` of the inscription.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:min-chars] property.
Since: 4.8

parameter.parameter_description: the minimum number of characters that should fit, approximately

Sets the `min-lines` of the inscription.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_nat_chars
function.description:

See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:nat-chars] property.

Sets the `nat-lines` of the inscription.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_text
function.description:
Sets the text to be displayed.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_text_overflow
function.description:
Sets what to do when the text doesn't fit.

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_wrap_mode
function.description:
Controls how line wrapping is done.
Since:4.8

function.name: gtk_inscription_set_xalign
function.description:
Sets the `xalign` of the inscription.
See the [property@Gtk.Inscription:xalign] property.

function.name: gtk_is_initialized
function.description:
Returns whether GTK has been initialized.
See [func@Gtk.init].

function.name: gtk_keyval_trigger_get_keyval
function.description: Gets the keyval that must be pressed to succeed triggering @self.

function.name: gtk_keyval_trigger_get_modifiers
function.description: Gets the modifiers that must be present to succeed triggering @self.

function.name: gtk_keyval_trigger_new
function.description: Creates a `GtkShortcutTrigger` that will trigger whenever the key with the given @keyval and @modifiers is pressed.

parameter.name: modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: the modifiers that need to be present

function.name: gtk_label_get_attributes
function.description:
Gets the label's attribute list.
This is the [struct@Pango.AttrList] that was set on the label using [method@Gtk.Label.set_attributes], if any. This function does not reflect attributes that come from the label's markup (see [method@Gtk.Label.set_markup]). If you want to get the effective attributes for the label, use `pango_layout_get_attributes (gtk_label_get_layout (self))`.

function.name: gtk_label_get_current_uri
function.description:
Returns the URI for the active link in the label.
The active link is the one under the mouse pointer or, in a selectable label, the link in which the text cursor is currently positioned.
This function is intended for use in a [signal@Gtk.Label::activate-link] handler or for use in a [signal@Gtk.Widget::query-tooltip] handler.

function.name: gtk_label_get_ellipsize
function.description:
Returns the ellipsization mode of the label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_ellipsize].

function.name: gtk_label_get_extra_menu
function.description:
Gets the extra menu model of the label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_extra_menu].

function.name: gtk_label_get_justify
function.description:
Returns the justification of the label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_justify].

function.name: gtk_label_get_label
function.description:
Fetches the text from a label.
The returned text includes any embedded underlines indicating mnemonics and Pango markup. (See [method@Gtk.Label.get_text]).
function.return: the text of the label widget

function.name: gtk_label_get_layout
function.description:
Gets the Pango layout used to display the label.
The layout is useful to e.g. convert text positions to pixel positions, in combination with [method@Gtk.Label.get_layout_offsets]. The returned layout is owned by the @label so need not be freed by the caller. The @label is free to recreate its layout at any time, so it should be considered read-only.

function.name: gtk_label_get_layout_offsets
function.description:
Obtains the coordinates where the label will draw its Pango layout.
The coordinates are useful to convert mouse events into coordinates inside the [class@Pango.Layout], e.g. to take some action if some part of the label is clicked. Remember when using the [class@Pango.Layout] functions you need to convert to and from pixels using `PANGO_PIXELS()` or [const@Pango.SCALE].

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: location to store X offset of layout

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to store Y offset of layout

function.name: gtk_label_get_lines
function.description:
Gets the number of lines to which an ellipsized, wrapping label should be limited.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_lines].

function.name: gtk_label_get_max_width_chars
function.description:
Retrieves the maximum width of the label in characters.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_width_chars].
function.return: the maximum width of the label, in characters

function.name: gtk_label_get_measuring_layout
function.description:
Gets a layout that can be used for measuring sizes.
The returned layout will be identical to the label’s layout except for the layout’s width, which will be set to @width. Do not modify the returned layout.

parameter.name: existing_layout
parameter.parameter_description: an existing layout already in use

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width to measure with, in Pango units, or -1 for infinite

function.name: gtk_label_get_mnemonic_keyval
function.description:
Return the mnemonic accelerator.
If the label has been set so that it has a mnemonic key this function returns the keyval used for the mnemonic accelerator. If there is no mnemonic set up it returns `GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol`.
function.return: GDK keyval usable for accelerators, or `GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol`

function.name: gtk_label_get_mnemonic_widget
function.description:
Retrieves the mnemonic target of this label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_mnemonic_widget].
function.return: the target of the label’s mnemonic, or `NULL` if none has been set and the default algorithm will be used.

function.name: gtk_label_get_natural_wrap_mode
function.description:
Returns natural line wrap mode used by the label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_natural_wrap_mode].
Since: 4.6

function.name: gtk_label_get_selectable
function.description: Returns whether the label is selectable.
function.return: true if the user can copy text from the label

function.name: gtk_label_get_selection_bounds
function.description:
Gets the selected range of characters in the label.
The returned @start and @end positions are in characters.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of selection

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of selection

function.name: gtk_label_get_single_line_mode
function.description: Returns whether the label is in single line mode.
function.return: true if the label is in single line mode

function.name: gtk_label_get_tabs
function.description:
Gets the tab stops for the label.
The returned array will be `NULL` if “standard” (8-space) tabs are used.
Since: 4.8
function.return: copy of default tab array, or `NULL` if standard tabs are used

function.name: gtk_label_get_text
function.description:
Gets the text of the label.
The returned text is as it appears on screen. This does not include any embedded underlines indicating mnemonics or Pango markup. (See [method@Gtk.Label.get_label])
function.return: the text in the label widget

function.name: gtk_label_get_use_markup
function.description:
Returns whether the label’s text is interpreted as Pango markup.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_use_markup].
function.return: true if the label’s text will be parsed for markup

function.name: gtk_label_get_use_underline
function.description:
Returns whether underlines in the label indicate mnemonics.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_use_underline].
function.return: true if underlines in the label indicate mnemonics

function.name: gtk_label_get_width_chars
function.description:
Retrieves the desired width of the label in characters.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_width_chars].
function.return: the desired width of the label, in characters

function.name: gtk_label_get_wrap
function.description:
Returns whether lines in the label are automatically wrapped.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_wrap].
function.return: true if the lines of the label are automatically wrapped

function.name: gtk_label_get_wrap_mode
function.description:
Returns line wrap mode used by the label.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_wrap_mode].

function.name: gtk_label_get_xalign
function.description:
Gets the `xalign` of the label.
See the [property@Gtk.Label:xalign] property.

function.name: gtk_label_get_yalign
function.description:
Gets the `yalign` of the label.
See the [property@Gtk.Label:yalign] property.

function.name: gtk_label_new
function.description:
Creates a new label with the given text inside it.
You can pass `NULL` to get an empty label widget.

function.name: gtk_label_new_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Creates a new label with the given text inside it, and a mnemonic.
If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined. If you need a literal underscore character in a label, use '__' (two underscores). The first underlined character represents a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic. The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using [method@Gtk.Label.set_mnemonic_widget].
If [method@Gtk.Label.set_mnemonic_widget] is not called, then the first activatable ancestor of the label will be chosen as the mnemonic widget. For instance, if the label is inside a button or menu item, the button or menu item will automatically become the mnemonic widget and be activated by the mnemonic.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: the text of the label, with an underscore in front of the mnemonic character

function.name: gtk_label_select_region
function.description:
Selects a range of characters in the label, if the label is selectable.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_selectable]. If the label is not selectable, this function has no effect. If @start_offset or @end_offset are -1, then the end of the label will be substituted.

function.name: gtk_label_set_attributes
function.description:
Apply attributes to the label text.
The attributes set with this function will be applied and merged with any other attributes previously effected by way of the [property@Gtk.Label:use-underline] or [property@Gtk.Label:use-markup] properties
While it is not recommended to mix markup strings with manually set attributes, if you must; know that the attributes will be applied to the label after the markup string is parsed.

function.name: gtk_label_set_ellipsize
function.description:
Sets the mode used to ellipsize the text.
The text will be ellipsized if there is not enough space to render the entire string.

function.name: gtk_label_set_extra_menu
function.description: Sets a menu model to add to the context menu of the label.

function.name: gtk_label_set_justify
function.description:
Sets the alignment of lines in the label relative to each other.
This function has no effect on labels containing only a single line.
[enum@Gtk.Justification.left] is the default value when the widget is first created with [ctor@Gtk.Label.new].
If you instead want to set the alignment of the label as a whole, use [method@Gtk.Widget.set_halign] instead.

function.name: gtk_label_set_label
function.description:
Sets the text of the label.
The label is interpreted as including embedded underlines and/or Pango markup depending on the values of the [property@Gtk.Label:use-underline] and [property@Gtk.Label:use-markup] properties.

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: the new text to set for the label

function.name: gtk_label_set_lines
function.description:
Sets the number of lines to which an ellipsized, wrapping label should be limited.
This has no effect if the label is not wrapping or ellipsized. Set this to -1 if you don’t want to limit the number of lines.

parameter.name: lines
parameter.parameter_description: the desired number of lines, or -1

function.name: gtk_label_set_markup
gtk_label_set_markup_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Sets the labels text, attributes and mnemonic from markup.
Parses @str which is marked up with Pango markup (see [func@Pango.parse_markup]), setting the label’s text and attribute list based on the parse results. If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined indicating that they represent a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic.
The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using [method@Gtk.Label.set_mnemonic_widget].

function.name: gtk_label_set_max_width_chars
function.description: Sets the maximum width of the label in characters.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the new maximum width, in characters.

function.name: gtk_label_set_mnemonic_widget
function.description:
Associate the label with its mnemonic target.
If the label has been set so that it has a mnemonic key (using i.e. [method@Gtk.Label.set_markup_with_mnemonic], [method@Gtk.Label.set_text_with_mnemonic], [ctor@Gtk.Label.new_with_mnemonic] or the [property@Gtk.Label:use_underline] property) the label can be associated with a widget that is the target of the mnemonic. When the label is inside a widget (like a [class@Gtk.Button] or a [class@Gtk.Notebook] tab) it is automatically associated with the correct widget, but sometimes (i.e. when the target is a [class@Gtk.Entry] next to the label) you need to set it explicitly using this function.
The target widget will be accelerated by emitting the [signal@Gtk.Widget::mnemonic-activate] signal on it. The default handler for this signal will activate the widget if there are no mnemonic collisions and toggle focus between the colliding widgets otherwise.

function.name: gtk_label_set_natural_wrap_mode
function.description:
Selects the line wrapping for the natural size request.
This only affects the natural size requested, for the actual wrapping used, see the [property@Gtk.Label:wrap-mode] property.
Since: 4.6

function.name: gtk_label_set_selectable
function.description:
Makes text in the label selectable.
Selectable labels allow the user to select text from the label, for copy-and-paste.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: true to allow selecting text in the label

function.name: gtk_label_set_single_line_mode
function.description: Sets whether the label is in single line mode.

parameter.name: single_line_mode
parameter.parameter_description: true to enable single line mode

function.name: gtk_label_set_tabs
function.description:
Sets tab stops for the label.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gtk_label_set_text
function.description:
Sets the text for the label.
It overwrites any text that was there before and clears any previously set mnemonic accelerators, and sets the [property@Gtk.Label:use-underline] and [property@Gtk.Label:use-markup] properties to false.
Also see [method@Gtk.Label.set_markup].

function.name: gtk_label_set_text_with_mnemonic
function.description:
Sets the text for the label, with mnemonics.
If characters in @str are preceded by an underscore, they are underlined indicating that they represent a keyboard accelerator called a mnemonic. The mnemonic key can be used to activate another widget, chosen automatically, or explicitly using [method@Gtk.Label.set_mnemonic_widget].

function.name: gtk_label_set_use_markup
function.description:
Sets whether the text of the label contains markup.
See [method@Gtk.Label.set_markup].

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: true if the label’s text should be parsed for markup.

function.name: gtk_label_set_use_underline
function.description: Sets whether underlines in the text indicate mnemonics.

parameter.name: setting
parameter.parameter_description: true if underlines in the text indicate mnemonics

function.name: gtk_label_set_width_chars
function.description: Sets the desired width in characters of the label.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the new desired width, in characters.

function.name: gtk_label_set_wrap
function.description:
Toggles line wrapping within the label.
True makes it break lines if text exceeds the widget’s size. false lets the text get cut off by the edge of the widget if it exceeds the widget size.
Note that setting line wrapping to true does not make the label wrap at its parent widget’s width, because GTK widgets conceptually can’t make their requisition depend on the parent widget’s size. For a label that wraps at a specific position, set the label’s width using [method@Gtk.Widget.set_size_request].

function.name: gtk_label_set_wrap_mode
function.description:
Controls how line wrapping is done.
This only affects the label if line wrapping is on. (See [method@Gtk.Label.set_wrap])
The default is [enum@Pango.WrapMode.word], which means wrap on word boundaries.
For sizing behavior, also consider the [property@Gtk.Label:natural-wrap-mode] property.

function.name: gtk_label_set_xalign
function.description:
Sets the `xalign` of the label.
See the [property@Gtk.Label:xalign] property.

parameter.name: xalign
parameter.parameter_description: the new xalign value, between 0 and 1

function.name: gtk_label_set_yalign
function.description:
Sets the `yalign` of the label.
See the [property@Gtk.Label:yalign] property.

parameter.name: yalign
parameter.parameter_description: the new yalign value, between 0 and 1

function.name: gtk_layout_child_get_child_widget
function.description: Retrieves the `GtkWidget` associated to the given @layout_child.

function.name: gtk_layout_child_get_layout_manager
function.description: Retrieves the `GtkLayoutManager` instance that created the given @layout_child.

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_allocate
function.description: Assigns the given @width, @height, and @baseline to a @widget, and computes the position and sizes of the children of the @widget using the layout management policy of @manager.

parameter.name: baseline
parameter.parameter_description: the baseline position of the @widget, or -1

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_get_layout_child
function.description:
Retrieves a `GtkLayoutChild` instance for the `GtkLayoutManager`, creating one if necessary.
The @child widget must be a child of the widget using @manager.
The `GtkLayoutChild` instance is owned by the `GtkLayoutManager`, and is guaranteed to exist as long as @child is a child of the `GtkWidget` using the given `GtkLayoutManager`.

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_get_request_mode
function.description: Retrieves the request mode of @manager.

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_get_widget
function.description: Retrieves the `GtkWidget` using the given `GtkLayoutManager`.

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_layout_changed
function.description:
Queues a resize on the `GtkWidget` using @manager, if any.
This function should be called by subclasses of `GtkLayoutManager` in response to changes to their layout management policies.

function.name: gtk_layout_manager_measure
function.description:
Measures the size of the @widget using @manager, for the given @orientation and size.
See the [class@Gtk.Widget] documentation on layout management for more details.

parameter.name: for_size
parameter.parameter_description: Size for the opposite of @orientation; for instance, if the @orientation is %GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL, this is the height of the widget; if the @orientation is %GTK_ORIENTATION_VERTICAL, this is the width of the widget. This allows to measure the height for the given width, and the width for the given height. Use -1 if the size is not known

parameter.name: minimum
parameter.parameter_description: the minimum size for the given size and orientation

parameter.name: natural
parameter.parameter_description: the natural, or preferred size for the given size and orientation

parameter.name: minimum_baseline
parameter.parameter_description: the baseline position for the minimum size

parameter.name: natural_baseline
parameter.parameter_description: the baseline position for the natural size

function.name: gtk_level_bar_add_offset_value
function.description:
Adds a new offset marker on @self at the position specified by @value.
When the bar value is in the interval topped by @value (or between @value and [property@Gtk.LevelBar:max-value] in case the offset is the last one on the bar) a style class named `level-`@name will be applied when rendering the level bar fill.
If another offset marker named @name exists, its value will be replaced by @value.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new offset

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value for the new offset

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_inverted
function.description: Returns whether the levelbar is inverted.
function.return: %TRUE if the level bar is inverted

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_max_value
function.description: Returns the `max-value` of the `GtkLevelBar`.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_min_value
function.description: Returns the `min-value` of the `GtkLevelBar`.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_mode
function.description: Returns the `mode` of the `GtkLevelBar`.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_offset_value
function.description: Fetches the value specified for the offset marker @name in @self.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an offset in the bar

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location where to store the value

function.return: %TRUE if the specified offset is found

function.name: gtk_level_bar_get_value
function.description: Returns the `value` of the `GtkLevelBar`.
function.return: a value in the interval between [property@Gtk.LevelBar:min-value] and [property@Gtk.LevelBar:max-value]

function.name: gtk_level_bar_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkLevelBar`.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_new_for_interval
function.description: Creates a new `GtkLevelBar` for the specified interval.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_remove_offset_value
function.description:
Removes an offset marker from a `GtkLevelBar`.
The marker must have been previously added with [method@Gtk.LevelBar.add_offset_value].

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an offset in the bar

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_inverted
function.description: Sets whether the `GtkLevelBar` is inverted.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_max_value
function.description:
Sets the `max-value` of the `GtkLevelBar`.
You probably want to update preexisting level offsets after calling this function.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_min_value
function.description:
Sets the `min-value` of the `GtkLevelBar`.
You probably want to update preexisting level offsets after calling this function.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_mode
function.description: Sets the `mode` of the `GtkLevelBar`.

function.name: gtk_level_bar_set_value
function.description: Sets the value of the `GtkLevelBar`.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a value in the interval between [property@Gtk.LevelBar:min-value] and [property@Gtk.LevelBar:max-value]

function.name: gtk_link_button_get_uri
function.description: Retrieves the URI of the `GtkLinkButton`.
function.return: a valid URI. The returned string is owned by the link button and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: gtk_link_button_get_visited
function.description:
Retrieves the “visited” state of the `GtkLinkButton`.
The button becomes visited when it is clicked. If the URI is changed on the button, the “visited” state is unset again.
The state may also be changed using [method@Gtk.LinkButton.set_visited].
function.return: %TRUE if the link has been visited, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_link_button_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkLinkButton` with the URI as its text.

function.name: gtk_link_button_new_with_label
function.description: Creates a new `GtkLinkButton` containing a label.

function.name: gtk_link_button_set_uri
function.description:
Sets @uri as the URI where the `GtkLinkButton` points.
As a side-effect this unsets the “visited” state of the button.

function.name: gtk_link_button_set_visited
function.description:
Sets the “visited” state of the `GtkLinkButton`.
See [method@Gtk.LinkButton.get_visited] for more details.

function.name: gtk_list_base_set_anchor_max_widgets
function.description:
Sets how many widgets should be kept alive around the anchor. The number of these widgets determines how many items can be displayed and must be chosen to be large enough to cover the allocation but should be kept as small as possible for performance reasons.
There will be @center widgets allocated around the anchor evenly distributed according to the anchor's alignment - if the anchor is at the start, all these widgets will be allocated behind it, if it's at the end, all the widgets will be allocated in front of it.
Additionally, there will be @above_below widgets allocated both before and after the center widgets, so the total number of widgets kept alive is 2 * above_below + center + 1.

parameter.name: center
parameter.parameter_description: the number of widgets in the middle

function.name: gtk_list_box_append
function.description:
Append a widget to the list.
If a sort function is set, the widget will actually be inserted at the calculated position.

function.name: gtk_list_box_bind_model
function.description:
Binds @model to @box.
If @box was already bound to a model, that previous binding is destroyed.
The contents of @box are cleared and then filled with widgets that represent items from @model. @box is updated whenever @model changes. If @model is %NULL, @box is left empty.
It is undefined to add or remove widgets directly (for example, with [method@Gtk.ListBox.insert]) while @box is bound to a model.
Note that using a model is incompatible with the filtering and sorting functionality in `GtkListBox`. When using a model, filtering and sorting should be implemented by the model.

parameter.name: create_widget_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function that creates widgets for items or %NULL in case you also passed %NULL as @model

function.name: gtk_list_box_drag_highlight_row
function.description:
Add a drag highlight to a row.
This is a helper function for implementing DnD onto a `GtkListBox`. The passed in @row will be highlighted by setting the %GTK_STATE_FLAG_DROP_ACTIVE state and any previously highlighted row will be unhighlighted.
The row will also be unhighlighted when the widget gets a drag leave event.

function.name: gtk_list_box_drag_unhighlight_row
function.description: If a row has previously been highlighted via gtk_list_box_drag_highlight_row(), it will have the highlight removed.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_activate_on_single_click
function.description: Returns whether rows activate on single clicks.
function.return: %TRUE if rows are activated on single click, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_adjustment
function.description: Gets the adjustment (if any) that the widget uses to for vertical scrolling.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_row_at_index
function.description:
Gets the n-th child in the list (not counting headers).
If @index_ is negative or larger than the number of items in the list, %NULL is returned.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_row_at_y
function.description: Gets the row at the @y position.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_selected_row
function.description:
Gets the selected row, or %NULL if no rows are selected.
Note that the box may allow multiple selection, in which case you should use [method@Gtk.ListBox.selected_foreach] to find all selected rows.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_selected_rows
function.description: Creates a list of all selected children.
function.return: A `GList` containing the `GtkWidget` for each selected child. Free with g_list_free() when done.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_selection_mode
function.description: Gets the selection mode of the listbox.

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_show_separators
function.description: Returns whether the list box should show separators between rows.
function.return: %TRUE if the list box shows separators

function.name: gtk_list_box_get_tab_behavior
function.description:
Returns the behavior of the <kbd>Tab</kbd> and <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Tab</kbd> keys.
Since: 4.18

function.name: gtk_list_box_insert
function.description:
Insert the @child into the @box at @position.
If a sort function is set, the widget will actually be inserted at the calculated position.
If @position is -1, or larger than the total number of items in the @box, then the @child will be appended to the end.

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_filter
function.description:
Update the filtering for all rows.
Call this when result of the filter function on the @box is changed due to an external factor. For instance, this would be used if the filter function just looked for a specific search string and the entry with the search string has changed.

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_headers
function.description:
Update the separators for all rows.
Call this when result of the header function on the @box is changed due to an external factor.

function.name: gtk_list_box_invalidate_sort
function.description:
Update the sorting for all rows.
Call this when result of the sort function on the @box is changed due to an external factor.

function.name: gtk_list_box_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkListBox` container.

function.name: gtk_list_box_prepend
function.description:
Prepend a widget to the list.
If a sort function is set, the widget will actually be inserted at the calculated position.

function.name: gtk_list_box_remove
function.description: Removes a child from @box.

function.name: gtk_list_box_remove_all
function.description:
Removes all rows from @box.
This function does nothing if @box is backed by a model.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_changed
function.description:
Marks @row as changed, causing any state that depends on this to be updated.
This affects sorting, filtering and headers.
Note that calls to this method must be in sync with the data used for the row functions. For instance, if the list is mirroring some external data set, and *two* rows changed in the external data set then when you call gtk_list_box_row_changed() on the first row the sort function must only read the new data for the first of the two changed rows, otherwise the resorting of the rows will be wrong.
This generally means that if you don’t fully control the data model you have to duplicate the data that affects the listbox row functions into the row widgets themselves. Another alternative is to call [method@Gtk.ListBox.invalidate_sort] on any model change, but that is more expensive.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_activatable
function.description: Gets whether the row is activatable.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_child
function.description: Gets the child widget of @row.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_header
function.description:
Returns the current header of the @row.
This can be used in a [callback@Gtk.ListBoxUpdateHeaderFunc] to see if there is a header set already, and if so to update the state of it.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_index
function.description: Gets the current index of the @row in its `GtkListBox` container.
function.return: the index of the @row, or -1 if the @row is not in a listbox

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_get_selectable
function.description: Gets whether the row can be selected.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_is_selected
function.description: Returns whether the child is currently selected in its `GtkListBox` container.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_new
function.description: Creates a new `GtkListBoxRow`.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_set_activatable
function.description: Set whether the row is activatable.

parameter.name: activatable
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to mark the row as activatable

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_set_child
function.description: Sets the child widget of @self.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_set_header
function.description:
Sets the current header of the @row.
This is only allowed to be called from a [callback@Gtk.ListBoxUpdateHeaderFunc]. It will replace any existing header in the row, and be shown in front of the row in the listbox.

function.name: gtk_list_box_row_set_selectable
function.description: Set whether the row can be selected.

parameter.name: selectable
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to mark the row as selectable

function.name: gtk_list_box_select_all
function.description: Select all children of @box, if the selection mode allows it.

function.name: gtk_list_box_select_row
